[[File:DBCooper.jpg|thumb|Composite sketch of a hijacker known only by the pseudonym [[D. B. Cooper]].]]
A '''facial composite''' is a graphical representation of one or more [[Witness|eyewitness]]es' memory of a face, as recorded by a composite artist. Facial composites are used mainly by police in their investigation of (usually serious) crimes. These images are also used to reconstruct the suspect's face in hope of identifying them.
==Methods==
===PhotoFIT generation=== Construction of the composite was originally performed by a trained artist, through drawing, sketching, or painting, in consultation with a witness or crime victim. Subsequently, techniques were devised for use by those less artistically skilled, employing interchangeable templates of separate facial features. The first such mechanical system, called "Identikit", was introduced in the U.S. in 1959; it used drawings of facial features on transparent acetate sheets that could be superimposed on one another to produce the composite image.<ref name="Davies-Valentine">{{cite book |last1=Davies |first1=Graham M. |last2=Valentine |first2=Tim |chapter=Facial Composites: Forensic Utility and Psychological Research |title=Handbook of Eyewitness Psychology |editor=Rod C. L. Lindsay, et al. (Eds.)|date=2006 |place=Mahwah, NJ |publisher=Lawrence Erlbaum Associates |isbn=9780805851526 |doi=10.4324/9781315805535 |volume=Vol. 2 ''Memory for People'' |at=Section, "Mechanical Systems" |via=''Routledge Handbooks Online'' (2014) |chapter-url=https://www.routledgehandbooks.com/doi/10.4324/9781315805535}}</ref> (A later version of Identikit is made by [[Smith & Wesson]].) In 1970, a system called "Photofit", which aimed for greater realism by using actual photographs of facial features, was introduced in the U.K.<ref name="Davies-Valentine"/>
In the last two decades, a number of computer based facial composite systems have been introduced; amongst the most widely used systems are SketchCop FACETTE Face Design System Software, "Identi-Kit 2000", FACES, [[E-FIT]] and PortraitPad. In the U.S. the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]] maintains that hand-drawing is its preferred method for constructing a facial composite. Many other police agencies, however, use software, since suitable artistic talent is often not available.
===Evolutionary systems=== Until quite recently, the facial composite systems used by international police forces were exclusively based on a construction methodology in which individual facial features (eyes, nose, mouth, eyebrows, etc.) are selected one at a time from a large database and then electronically 'overlaid' to make the composite image. Such systems are often referred to as feature-based since they essentially rely on the selection of individual features in isolation. However, after a long period of research and development work conducted largely within British universities, systems based on a rather different principle are finding increasing use by police forces.<ref>{{cite book |last=Frowd |first=C. D. |last2=Hancock |first2=P. J. B. |last3=Bruce |first3=V. |last4=McIntyre |first4=A. |last5=Pitchford |first5=M. |last6=Atkins |first6=R. |chapter=Giving crime the 'evo': catching criminals using EvoFIT facial composites |editor1-first=G. |editor1-last=Howells |editor2-first=K. |editor2-last=Sirlantzis |editor3-first=A. |editor3-last=Stoica |editor4-first=T. |editor4-last=Huntsberger |editor5-first=A. T. |editor5-last=Arslan |title=2010 IEEE International Conference on Emerging Security Technologies |year=2010 |pages=36‚Äì43 |isbn=978-0-7695-4175-4 |display-authors=etal}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |first=S. J. |last=Gibson |first2=C. J. |last2=Solomon |first3=M. I. S. |last3=Maylin |first4=C. |last4=Clark |title=New methodology in facial composite construction: from theory to practice |journal=Int. J.Electronic Security and Digital Forensics |year=2009 |volume=2 |issue=2 |pages=156‚Äì168 |doi=10.1504/IJESDF.2009.0249 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=Solomon |first=C. |last2=Gibson |first2=S. |last3=Maylin |first3=M. |chapter=A New Computational Methodology for the Construction of Forensic, Facial Composites |title=Computational Forensics |publisher=Springer-Verlag LNCS |year=2009 |pages=67‚Äì77 |isbn=9783540853022 }}</ref> These systems may be broadly described as holistic or global in that they primarily attempt to create a likeness to the suspect through an [[genetic algorithm|evolutionary mechanism]] in which a witness's response to groups of complete faces (not just features) converges towards an increasingly accurate image. Three such systems have come from academic beginnings, EFIT-V from the University of Kent;<ref name=Revolution>{{cite journal | title=A (r)evolution in Crime-fighting. | author=Craig Aaen Stockdale | date=June 1, 2008 | url=http://www.forensicmag.com/article/revolution-crime-fighting | journal=Forensic Magazine}}</ref> EvoFIT (http://www.EvoFIT.co.uk) from the University of Stirling, the University of Central Lancashire (UCLan) and the University of Winchester;<ref name="Frowd 2013 89‚Äì97">{{cite journal |last=Frowd |first=C. D. |last2=Skelton |first2=F. |last3=Hepton |first3=G. |last4=Holden |first4=L. |last5=Minahil |first5=S. |last6=Pitchford |first6=M. |last7=McIntyre |first7=A. |last8=Hancock |first8=P. J. B. |year=2013 |title=Whole-face procedures for recovering facial images from memory |journal=Science & Justice |volume=53 |issue=2 |pages=89‚Äì97 |doi=10.1016/j.scijus.2012.12.004 }}</ref> and ID from the University of Cape Town, South Africa. GFE<ref>https://sites.google.com/view/facevisionresearch</ref> is an experimental evolutionary face compositing system using image gradient instead of luminance to represent faces, which seems to produce better quality composites.<ref>Garc√≠a-Zurdo, R. "Evolving Faces in Gradient Space". Conference of the British Psychological Society, Cognitive Psychology Section. Barcelona, September 2016.</ref>
==Research== A general review of research into the evaluation of mechanical template techniques may be found in Davies and Valentine (2006).<ref>{{cite book |last=Davies |first=G. M. |last2=Valentine |first2=T. |year=2006 |chapter=Facial composites: Forensic utility and psychological research |title=Handbook of Eyewitness Psychology |editor1-first=R. C. L. |editor1-last=Lindsay |editor2-first=D. F. |editor2-last=Ross |editor3-first=J. D. |editor3-last=Read |editor4-first=M. P. |editor4-last=Toglia | displayeditors=3|volume=2 |pages=59‚Äì96 |location=Mahwah, NJ |publisher=Erlbaum |isbn=9780805851526 }}</ref> A review of research into more modern 'feature' and 'recognition' systems, and into methods for improving the effectiveness of composites, may be found in Frowd et al. (2008)<ref>{{cite journal |last=Frowd |first=C. D. |last2=Bruce |first2=V. |last3=Hancock |first3=P. J. B. |year=2008 |title=Changing the face of criminal identification |journal=The Psychologist |volume=21 |issue=8 |pages=670‚Äì672 |doi= }}</ref> and (2009).<ref>{{cite journal |last=Frowd |first=C. D. |last2=Bruce |first2=V. |last3=Hancock |first3=P. J. B. |year=2009 |title=Evolving facial composite systems |journal=Forensic Update |volume=98 |issue= |pages=25‚Äì32 |doi= }}</ref>
The systems used in the UK have been subjected to a number of academic studies. These have typically shown that E-FIT and PRO-fit produce composites that are correctly named, either immediately or a few hours after construction, about 20% of the time (see Brace et al. (2000),<ref>{{cite book |last=Brace |first=N. |last2=Pike |first2=G. |last3=Kemp |first3=R. |year=2000 |chapter=Investigating E-FIT using famous faces |title=Forensic Psychology and Law |editor1-first=A. |editor1-last=Czerederecka |editor2-first=T. |editor2-last=Jaskiewicz-Obydzinska |editor3-first=J. |editor3-last=Wojcikiewicz |pages=272‚Äì276 |publisher=Krakow Institute of Forensic Research Publishers |location= |isbn=978-0-470-09623-9}}</ref> Bruce et al. (2002),<ref>{{cite journal |last=Bruce |first=V. |last2=Ness |first2=H. |last3=Hancock |first3=P. J. B. |last4=Newman |first4=C. |last5=Rarity |first5=J. |year=2002 |title=Four heads are better than one: Combining face composites yields improvements in face likeness |journal=[[Journal of Applied Psychology]] |volume=87 |issue=5 |pages=894‚Äì902 |doi=10.1037/0021-9010.87.5.894 }}</ref> Davies et al. (2000)<ref>{{cite journal |last=Davies |first=G. M. |last2=Van Der Willie |first2=P. |last3=Morrison |first3=L. J. |year=2000 |title=Facial composite production: A comparison of mechanical and computer driven systems |journal=[[Journal of Applied Psychology]] |volume=85 |issue=1 |pages=119‚Äì124 |doi=10.1037/0021-9010.85.1.119 |pmid=10740962 }}</ref> and Frowd et al. (2005)<ref>{{cite journal |last=Frowd |first=C. D. |last2=Carson |first2=D. |last3=Ness |first3=H. |last4=Richardson |first4=J. |last5=Morrison |first5=L. |last6=McLanaghan |first6=S. |last7=Hancock |first7=P. J. B. |year=2005 |title=A forensically valid comparison of facial composite systems |journal=Psychology, Crime & Law |volume=11 |issue=1 |pages=33‚Äì52 |doi=10.1080/10683160310001634313 }}</ref>). When witnesses in these studies are required to wait two days before constructing a composite, which matches real use more closely, naming falls to a few percent at best (e.g. Frowd et al. [2005]<ref>{{cite journal |last=Frowd |first=C. D. |last2=Carson |first2=D. |last3=Ness |first3=H. |last4=McQuiston |first4=D. |last5=Richardson |first5=J. |last6=Baldwin |first6=H. |last7=Hancock |first7=P. J. B. |year=2005 |title=Contemporary composite techniuqes: the impact of a forensically-relevant target delay |journal=Legal and Criminological Psychology |volume=10 |issue=1 |pages=63‚Äì81 |doi=10.1348/135532504X15358 }}</ref> and [2007]<ref>{{cite journal |last=Frowd |first=C. D. |last2=Bruce |first2=V. |last3=Ness |first3=H. |last4=Bowie |first4=L. |last5=Thomson-Bogner |first5=C. |last6=Paterson |first6=J. |last7=McIntyre |first7=A. |last8=Hancock |first8=P. J. B. |year=2007 |title=Parallel approaches to composite production |journal=Ergonomics |volume=50 |issue=4 |pages=562‚Äì585 |doi=10.1080/00140130601154855 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last=Frowd |first=C. D. |last2=McQuiston-Surrett |first2=D. |last3=Anandaciva |first3=S. |last4=Ireland |first4=C. E. |last5=Hancock |first5=P. J. B. |year=2007 |title=An evaluation of US systems for facial composite production |journal=Ergonomics |volume=50 |issue=12 |pages=1987‚Äì1998 |doi=10.1080/00140130701523611 }}</ref>). The reason for the low level of naming from these systems appears to be that witnesses are unable to accurately construct the internal features of the face after long delays, the region that is important for recognition by another person later (Frowd et al. [2007]<ref>{{cite journal |last=Frowd |first=C. D. |last2=Bruce |first2=V. |last3=McIntyre |first3=A. |last4=Hancock |first4=P. J. B. |year=2007 |title=The relative importance of external and internal features of facial composites |journal=[[British Journal of Psychology]] |volume=98 |issue=1 |pages=61‚Äì77 |doi=10.1348/000712606X104481 }}</ref>).
Evolutionary systems show a marked improvement in accuracy. In academic trials, research on a fairly-recent version of the EvoFIT system has shown correct naming levels of about 30% after a 2-day delay (see Frowd et al., 2010).<ref>{{cite journal |last=Frowd |first=C. D. |last2=Pitchford |first2=M. |last3=Bruce |first3=V. |last4=Jackson |first4=S. |last5=Hepton |first5=G. |last6=Greenall |first6=M. |last7=McIntyre |first7=A. |last8=Hancock |first8=P. J. B. |year=2010 |title=The psychology of face construction: giving evolution a helping hand |journal=Applied Cognitive Psychology |volume=25 |issue=2 |pages=195‚Äì203 |doi=10.1002/acp.1662 }}</ref> Using more-recent construction techniques, the performance increased to 45% correct naming (Frowd et al., 2012).<ref>{{cite journal |last=Frowd |first=C. D. |last2=Skelton |first2=F. |last3=Atherton |first3=C. |last4=Pitchford |first4=M. |last5=Hepton |first5=G. |last6=Holden |first6=L. |last7=McIntyre |first7=A. |last8=Hancock |first8=P. J. B. |year=2012 |title=Recovering faces from memory: the distracting influence of external facial features |journal=Journal of Experimental Psychology: Applied |volume=18 |issue=2 |pages=224‚Äì238 |doi=10.1037/a0027393 |url=http://dspace.stir.ac.uk/bitstream/1893/3584/1/Frowd%20Recovering%20faces%20from%20memory_JEPA2012.pdf }}</ref> Using the very latest system, interview and enhancement techniques, naming of an EvoFIT composite is 74% correct (Frowd et al., 2013).<ref name="Frowd 2013 89‚Äì97"/> Appropriately, the system does appear to behave more like a face recognition than a face recall system (Frowd et al., 2011)<ref>{{cite journal |last=Frowd |first=C. D. |last2=Skelton |first2=F. |last3=Butt |first3=N. |last4=Hassan |first4=A. |last5=Fields |first5=S. |year=2011 |title=Familiarity effects in the construction of facial-composite images using modern software systems |journal=Ergonomics |volume=54 |issue=12 |pages=1147‚Äì1158 |doi=10.1080/00140139.2011.623328 }}</ref> Accompanying the development of EvoFIT have been new approaches in the type of interview administered to eyewitnesses prior to face construction (e.g. Frowd et al., 2012).<ref>{{cite journal |last=Frowd |first=C. D. |last2=Nelson |first2=L. |last3=Skelton |first3=F. C. |last4=Noyce |first4=R. |last5=Atkins |first5=R. |last6=Heard |first6=P. |last7=Morgan |first7=D. |last8=Fields |first8=S. |last9=Henry |first9=J. |last10=McIntyre |first10=A. |last11=Hancock |first11=P. J. B. |year=2012 |title=Interviewing techniques for Darwinian facial composite systems |journal=Applied Cognitive Psychology |volume=26 |issue=4 |pages=576‚Äì584 |doi=10.1002/acp.2829 }}</ref> Similarly in extensive field use EFIT-V has shown a 40% naming rate over an 18-month period with 1000 interviews.<ref>{{cite book |last=Solomon |first=C. |last2=Gibson |first2=S. |last3=Maylin |first3=M. |chapter=Generation of Facial Composites for Criminal Investigations |title=Craniofacial Identification |editor-first=Chris |editor-last=Rynn |publisher=Cambridge University Press |pages=67‚Äì77 |isbn=9780521768627 }}</ref> The EvoFIT system has been similarly evaluated in formal police field-trials.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Frowd |first=C. D. |last2=Hancock |first2=P. J. B. |last3=Bruce |first3=V. |last4=Skelton |first4=F. C. |last5=Atherton |first5=C. |last6=Nelson |first6=L. |year=2011 |title=Catching more offenders with EvoFIT facial composites: lab research and police field trials |journal=Global Journal of Human Social Science |volume=11 |issue=3 |pages=46‚Äì58 |doi= |url=http://www.socialscienceresearch.org/index.php/GJHSS/article/view/165 |display-authors=etal}}</ref> These evaluations have reported a much higher naming rate for EvoFIT composites but, using the latest interview techniques, a suspect arrest rate of 60%. This latest police field trial has also indicated that an EvoFIT directly leads to the arrest of a suspect and then a conviction in 29% of cases.<ref>{{cite book |last=Frowd |first=C. D. |last2=Pitchford |first2=M. |last3=Skelton |first3=F. |last4=Petkovic |first4=A. |last5=Prosser |first5=C. |last6=Coates |first6=B. |year=2012 |chapter=Catching Even More Offenders with EvoFIT Facial Composites |editor1-first=A. |editor1-last=Stoica |editor2-first=D. |editor2-last=Zarzhitsky |editor3-first=G. |editor3-last=Howells |editor4-first=C. |editor4-last=Frowd |editor5-first=K. |editor5-last=McDonald-Maier |editor6-first=A. |editor6-last=Erdogan |editor7-first=T. |editor7-last=Arslan |title=IEEE Proceedings of 2012 Third International Conference on Emerging Security Technologies |doi=10.1109/EST.2012.26 |pages=20‚Äì26 }}</ref> There have been many notable successes - for example, in this investigation, EvoFIT has directly led to the arrest of a [[serial rapist]].<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2019031/Evo-fit-New-facial-identification-technology-helps-catch-rapist-Asim-Javed.html | title=The changing face of crime: Powerful new Evo-fit technology helps catch rapist | author=Jaya Narain | date=27 July 2011 | location=London | work=Daily Mail}}</ref>
<gallery widths="180px" heights="200px"> File:Caesius facial composite.jpg| A facial composite produced by [[FACES]] software File:PortraitPad.jpg|A facial composite produced by [[PortraitPad ]] software </gallery>
==Usage== [[File:Aafia Siddiqui 2.png|thumb|right|Facial composite of [[Aafia Siddiqui]], created by the FBI for a wanted poster<ref name="emma">{{Cite news|last=Scroggins|first= Deborah|url=http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-6507794_ITM|title=The Most Wanted Woman in the World|publisher=[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]], reprinted by 'Access My Library'|format=Limited access, subscription required|date=March 1, 2005}}</ref>]] While the classic use of the facial composite is the citizen recognizing the face as an acquaintance, there are other ways where a facial composite can prove useful. The facial composite can contribute in law enforcement in a number of ways:
# Identifying the suspect in a [[wanted poster]]. # Additional evidence against a suspect.{{Citation needed|date=May 2008}} # Assisting investigation in checking leads. # Warning vulnerable population against serial offenders.
Facial composites of various types have been used extensively in those television programs which aim to reconstruct major unsolved crimes with a view to gaining information from the members of the public, such as "[[America's Most Wanted]]" in the US and "[[Crimewatch]]" in the UK.
==Notable cases== These notable cases had facial composites assist in identifying the perpetrator: * [[Oklahoma City]] bomber [[Timothy McVeigh]]. * [[Niklas Lindgren]], also known as "Hagamannen", a serial sexual assaulter in [[Ume√•]]. * [[Baton Rouge]] serial killer [[Derrick Todd Lee]]. * [[Manchester]] serial rapist Asim Javed.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2019031/Evo-fit-New-facial-identification-technology-helps-catch-rapist-Asim-Javed.html | location=London | work=Daily Mail | first=Jaya | last=Narain | title=The changing face of crime: Powerful new Evo-fit technology helps catch rapist | date=July 27, 2011}}</ref>

{{Environmental law}} [[File:Fishery Lake Tondano.JPG|thumb|Fishery on Lake Tondano, Indonesia]] '''Fisheries law''' is an emerging and specialized area of law. Fisheries law is the study and analysis of different [[fisheries management]] approaches such as catch shares e.g. [[Individual Transferable Quotas]]; TURFs; and others. The study of fisheries law is important in order to craft [[Environmental policy|policy]] guidelines that maximize [[Sustainability of fisheries|sustainability]] and legal enforcement.National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, Fisheries Service, available at http://www.nmfs.noaa.gov/aboutus.htm This specific legal area is rarely taught at law schools around the world, which leaves a vacuum of advocacy and research. Fisheries law also takes into account [[international treaties]] and [[Fishing industry|industry]] norms in order to analyze fisheries management regulations.Kevern L. Cochrane, A Fishery Manager‚Äôs Guidebook: Management Measures and their Application, Fisheries Technical Paper 424, available at ftp://ftp.fao.org/docrep/fao/004/y3427e/y3427e00.pdf In addition, fisheries law includes access to justice for small-scale fisheries and coastal and [[Indigenous peoples|aboriginal]] communities and labor issues such as child labor laws, employment law, and family law.Robert Stewart, Oceanography in the 21st Century ‚Äì An Online Textbook, Fisheries Issues, available at http://oceanworld.tamu.edu/resources/oceanography-book/fisheriesissues.htm Another important area of research covered in fisheries law is seafood safety. Each country, or region, around the world has a varying degree of seafood safety standards and regulations. These regulations can contain a large diversity of fisheries management schemes including quota or catch share systems. It is important to study seafood safety regulations around the world in order to craft policy guidelines from countries who have implemented effective schemes. Also, this body of research can identify areas of improvement for countries who have not yet been able to master efficient and effective seafood safety regulations. Fisheries law also includes the study of [[aquaculture]] laws and regulations. Aquaculture, also known as aquafarming, is the farming of aquatic organisms, such as fish and aquatic plants. This body of research also encompasses animal feed regulations and requirements. It is important to regulate what feed is consumed by fish in order to prevent risks to human health and safety. == Seafood Safety Regulations == === U.S. Labeling of Genetically Engineered Salmon === On November 19, 2015, the [[Food and Drug Administration|U.S. Food and Drug Administration]] (FDA) approved AquaBounty Technologies‚Äô application to sell the [[AquAdvantage salmon]] to U.S. consumers.FDA, ''AquAdvantage Salmon Approval Letter and Appendix'' (November 19, 2015), online: U.S. Food and Drug Administration <http://www.fda.gov>. The possible introduction of genetically engineered salmon into the marketplace furthers discussion involving ethics, protection of the natural environment, international and domestic trade law, labeling practices, nutrition, and constitutional issues. As the FDA points out, nutrition labeling for raw produce (fruits and vegetables), fish, and genetically modified products, is voluntary.FDA, ''Labeling & Nutrition'', online: U.S. Food and Drug Administration <http://www.fda.gov>. Under section 403(a)(1) of the ''[[Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act|Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act]]'' ("FD&C Act"), a food is misbranded if its labeling is ‚Äúfalse or misleading in any particular‚Äù.21 U.S.C. ¬ß 343(a)(1). Section 201(n) of the FD&C Act provides that labeling is misleading if it fails to reveal facts that are material in light of representations made or suggested in the labeling.21 U.S.C. ¬ß 321(n). In regards to the AquAdvantage salmon, the FDA has stated:
"Based on our assessments of food derived from the AquAdvantage Salmon, we have determined that the term ‚ÄúAtlantic salmon‚Äù is the appropriate common or usual name for such food within the meaning of section 403(i) of the FD&C Act because AquAdvantage Salmon meets FDA‚Äôs regulatory standard for Atlantic salmon (Ref. 10) and the composition and basic nature of food from AquAdvantage Salmon does not significantly differ from its non-GE counterpart‚Äînon-GE farm-raised Atlantic salmon. In addition, we have determined that food derived from AquAdvantage Salmon is as safe and nutritious as food from other farm-raised Atlantic salmon. For these reasons, we have concluded that there is no material difference between food derived from AquAdvantage Salmon and food derived from other non-GE, farm-raised Atlantic salmon that is required to be disclosed in the labeling of food derived from AquAdvantage Salmon under the relevant provisions of the FD&C Act, as explained above."{{Cite web|url=http://www.fda.gov/food/guidanceregulation/guidancedocumentsregulatoryinformation/ucm059098.htm|title=Draft Guidance for Industry: Voluntary Labeling Indicating Whether Food Has or Has Not Been Derived From Genetically Engineered Atlantic Salmon|last=|first=|date=November 19, 2015|website=Food|publisher=US FDA|access-date=}}
==== Canadian Labeling of Genetically Engineered Salmon ==== In 2014, Canada was a top-five producer of GM crops in the world, and is one of the largest players on the global market.ISAAA, ''Beyond Promises: Top 10 Facts about Biotech/GM Crops in 2014'', online: ISAA <http://www.isaaa.org>. Health Canada and the Canadian Food Inspection Agency ("CFIA") carry joint responsibility for federally food labeling policies in Canada under the ''Food and Drugs Act'' ("F&D Act").RSC 1985, c. F-27. Under the F&D Act, GMOs are defined as ‚Äúnovel foods‚Äù. A novel food is allowed to enter the Canadian marketplace only after it has passed an assessment undertaken by various stakeholders. Health Canada is responsible for deciding all health and safety labeling policies for food products, such as special dietary needs or GM products, and ensuring that the products are safe for consumption.Government of Canada, ''Labelling of Genetically Engineered Foods in Canada'', online: Canadian Food Inspection Agency <http://www.inspection.gc.ca> {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040403234714/http://www.inspection.gc.ca/ |date=April 3, 2004 }}. The CFIA is responsible for the development of all non-health and safety food labeling regulations and policies and the enforcement of labeling legislation. Standards are set by the CFIA so that Canadian food labels are truthful and not misleading. Subsection 5(1) of the F&D Act states that ‚Äúno person shall label, package, treat, process, sell or advertise any food in a manner that is false, misleading or deceptive or is likely to create an erroneous impression regarding its character, value, quantity, composition, merit or safety‚Äù. Food must be labelled only if there are changes in the food such as problematic allergens or a significant nutrient or compositional change. Health Canada has not released an official statement concerning the AquAdvantage salmon, but does state on its website: ‚Äúafter twelve years of reviewing the safety of novel foods, Health Canada is not aware of any published scientific evidence demonstrating that novel foods are any less safe than traditional foods. The regulatory framework put in place by the federal government ensures that new and modified foods can be safely introduced in to the Canadian diet‚Äù.Health Canada, ''Frequently Asked Questions ‚Äì Biotechnology and Genetically Modified Foods'', online: Food and Nutrition <http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca>. == See also == * [[Fisheries Law Centre]] * [[Fisheries management]] * [[Fisheries science]] * [[Illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing]] * [[Overfishing]] * [[Sustainable seafood]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{fishery science topics}} {{Natural resources}} [[Category:Fisheries law| ]]

{{Use British English|date=February 2014}} {{COI|date=August 2011}} {{Infobox law firm | name = Harbottle & Lewis LLP | logo = [[File:Harbottle&Lewis.jpg|frameless]] | headquarters = [[London]], {{postcode|W|1}}
[[United Kingdom]] | num_offices = One | num_lawyers = 128 | practice_areas = Media and entertainment law | revenue = {{profit}} ¬£28.1m | date_founded = 1955 | company_type = [[Limited liability partnership]] | homepage = [http://www.harbottle.com/ harbottle.com] }} '''Harbottle & Lewis''' is a [[law firm]] based in [[London]], [[United Kingdom]] which advises clients across the media, communications and entertainment industries.{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=1868347|title=Harbottle & Lewis LLP: Private Company Information - Businessweek|website=www.bloomberg.com|access-date=2016-05-18}} Harbottle & Lewis has 42 partners and 68 lawyers and in 2016/17 recorded turnover of ¬£28.1m.Matt Byrne, ''[[The Lawyer]]'', 16 August 2010, [http://www.thelawyer.com/harbottle-and-lewis/1005305.article Harbottle & Lewis] It is recommended by the independent legal directories The Legal 500 {{cite web|url=http://www.legal500.com/firms/1467/offices/224 |title=Legal 500 |publisher=Legal 500 |date= |accessdate=2013-07-04}} and Chambers and Partners{{cite web|url=http://www.chambersandpartners.com/UK/Firms/178-34245 |title=Chambers and Partners |publisher=Chambers and Partners |date= |accessdate=2013-07-04}} in all its core practice areas. == History == Laurence Harbottle and Brian Lewis met at Law School in [[Guildford]] in 1951.{{cite web|url=http://www.chambersstudent.co.uk/Law/FirmFeature/178 |title=''Chambers Student Guide'' |publisher=Chambersstudent.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2013-07-04}} Both lawyers had a special interest in the legal aspects of film production and theatre and in December 1955 established Harbottle & Lewis with its office in South Molton Street, [[Mayfair]]. While Brian Lewis concentrated on film guarantees and film productions, Laurence Harbottle mainly acted for film producers as well as writers, actors and technicians. With advances in technology, their firm grew and developed its television and music industry expertise. More recently Harbottle & Lewis has also built specialist practice areas in [[electronic commerce]] and interactive entertainment. The firm moved from South Molton Street to its current location on [[Hanover Square, London|Hanover Square]] in May 1988. Laurence Harbottle served as solicitor to friends [[Laurence Olivier]] and [[Dirk Bogarde]]. The firm's clients presently include [[Charles, Prince of Wales|The Prince of Wales]], and subsequently his sons [[Prince William, Duke of Cambridge|The Duke of Cambridge]] and [[Prince Harry, Duke of Sussex|The Duke of Sussex]]. ==Relations with News International== {{Main|News International phone hacking scandal#Harbottle and Lewis}} In 2006 Harbottle & Lewis acted on behalf of [[Charles, Prince of Wales|Prince Charles]] in engaging with the Metropolitan Police's investigations with regards to the hacking of the phones of his sons, Princes William and Harry, in the [[News of the World royal phone hacking scandal]].{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2015461/Why-did-Princes-lawyers-hide-hacking-evidence-Firm-advises-Royals-entangled-row-cover-up.html#ixzz1SLlwJKun|title=Why did Prince William's lawyers hide hacking evidence? Firm that advises Royals entangled in row over 'cover up'|author=Glen Owen|work=Daily Mail|date=17 July 2011|accessdate=17 July 2011}} That scandal subsequently led to the dismissal of ''[[News of the World]]'' reporter [[Clive Goodman]]. When Goodman [[News of the World royal phone hacking scandal#Unfair dismissal claim|sued for unfair dismissal]], Harbottle & Lewis were hired by the ''News of the World's'' parent company, [[News International]]. On 10 July 2011, Harbottle & Lewis acting for their client [[News International]] were cited by ''[[BBC News]]'' Business editor [[Robert Peston]] as being involved in the 'smoking gun' emails in the ''[[News of the World]]'' [[News of the World phone hacking scandal|phone hacking scandal]].[[Robert Peston]], ''[[BBC]]'', 10 July 2011, [https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-14099102 News International found "smoking gun" emails in 2007]{{cite web|url=http://lawyerwatch.wordpress.com/2011/07/10/hackgate-where-were-the-lawyers/ |title=Hackgate: where were the lawyers? |publisher=Lawyerwatch.wordpress.com |date=2011-07-10 |accessdate=2013-07-04}} On 18 July 2011, the firm issued an open letter outlining its position,''[[Legal Week]]'', 18 July 2011, [http://www.legalweek.com/legal-week/news/2094792/harbottle-defends-hackgate-position-grabiner-tipped-lead-newscorp-clean Harbottle defends Hackgate position; Grabiner to lead News Corp clean-up] and appointed Luther Pendragon to handle PR issues relating to the affair. On 19 July, Lord MacDonald the former Director of Public Prosecutions engaged by News Corporation to review the emails handed to Harbottle & Lewis in 2007, said in evidence to the [[Home Affairs Select Committee]]:BBC, 20 July 2011, [https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-14197962 Ex-Met Police chief denies 'swipe' at prime minister] {{cquote|I have to tell you that the material I saw was so blindingly obvious that anyone trying to argue that it shouldn't be given to the police would have had a very tough task}} On 20 July, Harbottle & Lewis issued a statement saying that it had asked News International to release it from its professional duty of confidentiality, which had been declined by News International. Harbottle & Lewis subsequently wrote to [[John Whittingdale]] MP, chairman of the [[Culture, Media and Sport Committee]], asking to provide evidence to the committee.Matt Byrne, ''[[The Lawyer]]'', 20 July 2011, [http://www.thelawyer.com/harbottle-forbidden-from-responding-to-news-internationals-put-down/1008692.article Harbottle forbidden from responding to News International's put-down] On 21 July it was reported that News International had authorised Harbottle & Lewis to answer questions from the Metropolitan Police Service and parliamentary select committees in respect of what they were asked to do.''[[The Independent]]'', 21 July 2011, [https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/law-firm-given-right-of-reply-over-failure-to-expose-bribery-2317840.html Law firm given right of reply over 'failure' to expose bribery] The Culture, Media and Sports Committee is reported to be planning to write to Harbottle & Lewis asking its representatives to appear when it resumes in October.''[[The Guardian]]'', 21 July 2011, [https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/jul/21/phone-hacking-harbottle-lewis-rupert-murdoch-select-committee Phone hacking: legal firm accused by Murdochs called before committee] Paul Farrelly, one of the MPs on the committee, said: {{cquote|Harbottle & Lewis stand right up there with all the other people who have come to us and maintained there was only one rogue reporter..... That letter has been allowed to lie on the record for four years when Harbottle & Lewis had other evidence from emails of wrongdoing that have now been finally provided to the police, so Harbottle & Lewis have a lot of questions to answer and we will be pursuing them. We don't know what Harbottle & Lewis were asked to review, we don't know what their brief was.}} He said that a letter written by the London law firm in 2007 to News International concerning a review of internal News of the World emails was now "clearly misleading". On 22 July, Tom Watson, another MP on the Committee, published a letter {{cite web |url=http://www.tom-watson.co.uk/2011/07/response-from-solicitors-regulation-authority-harbottle-lewis |title=Response from Solicitors Regulation Authority ‚Äì Harbottle & Lewis | Tom Watson MP |publisher=Tom-watson.co.uk |date=2011-07-22 |accessdate=2013-07-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110808150051/http://www.tom-watson.co.uk/2011/07/response-from-solicitors-regulation-authority-harbottle-lewis/ |archivedate=8 August 2011 |df=dmy-all }} from the [[Solicitors Regulation Authority]] in response to his letter expressing concerns about Harbottle and Lewis's part in the phone-hacking affair. In the letter, Anthony Townsend, Chief Executive of the SRA said: {{cquote|On the basis of our preliminary review of the public domain material, we have decided to instigate a formal investigation. We will pursue our investigation vigorously and thoroughly, but emphasise that our inquiries are at an early stage, and that no conclusions have been reached about whether there may have been any impropriety by any solicitor}} ==See also== * [[Metropolitan police role in phone hacking scandal]] * [[News International phone hacking scandal]] * [[Phone hacking scandal reference lists]] == References == {{Reflist|30em}} == External links == * [http://www.harbottle.com Harbottle & Lewis website] {{2011 News Corporation scandal}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2011}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Harbottle and Lewis}} [[Category:Law firms based in London]] [[Category:Intellectual property law firms]] [[Category:Law firms established in 1955]] [[Category:News International phone hacking scandal]] [[Category:British companies established in 1955]]

{{Infobox Beverage |name=Hires |image=[[Image:HiresRootBeerLogo.jpg|150px|Hires Root Beer Logo]] |type=[[Root Beer]] |manufacturer=[[Keurig Dr Pepper]] |origin=United States |introduced=1876 |discontinued= |color = Caramel |related=[[A&W Root Beer]], [[Dad's Root Beer]], [[Mug Root Beer]], [[Barq's]] |variants= |website= [http://www.drpeppersnapplegroup.com/brands/hires Keurig Dr Pepper] }}
'''Hires Root Beer''' is a [[root beer]] marketed by [[Keurig Dr Pepper]]. Introduced in 1876, it is considered the second longest continuously made [[soft drink]] in the United States. Only [[Vernors]] [[ginger ale]], dating to 1866, is older.
== History == [[File:All gone Could I have another glass of that Hires' Rootbeer.jpg|thumbnail|right|19th Century American Trade Card for Hires Root Beer, 1894.]] Hires Root Beer was created by [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania|Philadelphia]] [[pharmacist]] [[Charles Elmer Hires]]. The official story is that Hires first tasted [[root beer]], a traditional American beverage dating back to the colonial era, while on his honeymoon in 1875.<ref name=brands>{{cite web| url=http://www.drpeppersnapplegroup.com/brands/hires/| title=Our Brands| publisher=Keurig Dr Pepper| accessdate=2014-08-22}}</ref> However, historical accounts vary and the actual time and place of the discovery may never be known.<ref name=bennett>{{cite web| url=http://www.gourmetrootbeer.com/history.html#hires| title=Local Historians Argue Over the Root of Hires| first=Eileen| last=Bennett| date=June 28, 1998| work=[[The Press of Atlantic City]]| accessdate=2014-08-22}}</ref> By 1876, Hires had developed his own recipe and was marketing 25-cent packets of powder which each yielded five gallons of root beer. At Philadelphia's [[Centennial Exposition]] in 1876, he cultivated new customers by giving away free glasses of root beer. Hires marketed it as a solid concentrate of sixteen wild roots and berries. It claimed to purify the blood and make rosy cheeks.<ref name=pendergrast>{{cite book| authorlink=Mark Pendergrast| first=Mark| last=Pendergrast| year=2000| title=For God, Country and Coca-Cola| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bSAChoqpnHUC&q=hires#v=onepage&q=hires&f=false| page=14| publisher=Basic Books| isbn=978-0-46505-468-8| accessdate=2014-08-22}}</ref> In 1884, he began producing a liquid extract and a syrup for use in [[soda fountain]]s, and was soon shipping root beer in kegs and producing a special fountain dispenser called the "Hires Automatic Munimaker." In 1890, the Charles E. Hires Company incorporated and began supplying Hires root beer in small bottles<ref name=funderburg>{{cite book |title=Sundae best: a history of soda fountains |first=Anne Cooper | last=Funderburg |publisher=Bowling Green University Popular Press |location=[[Bowling Green, Ohio]] |year=2001 |isbn=978-0-87972-854-0 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Wr_yPYvkNWwC&pg=PA92| pages=92‚Äì94| accessdate=2014-08-22}}</ref><ref name=hoolihan>{{cite book |title=Social Medicine in the United States, 1717-1917| first=Christopher |last=Hoolihan |publisher=Boydell & Brewer |year=2001 |isbn=978-1-58046-098-9 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zFKvimYMHloC&pg=PA454 |page=454 |accessdate=2014-08-22}}</ref> claiming over a million bottles sold by 1891.<ref>{{cite web|title=Hires Root Beer|url=http://lcdl.library.cofc.edu/lcdl/catalog/lcdl:60538|website=Lowcountry Digital Library|accessdate=1 September 2014}}</ref>
But Hires's choice of name for his product caused a problem: the word "beer" drew the wrath of the [[temperance movement]]{{Citation needed|date=March 2009}}. He had his root beer tested by a laboratory, and trumpeted their conclusion that a glass of his root beer contained less alcohol than a loaf of bread.{{Citation needed|date=March 2009}} Hires Root Beer was promoted as "The Temperance Drink" and "the Greatest Health-Giving Beverage in the World." Hires advertised aggressively, believing "doing business without advertising is like winking at a girl in the dark. '''''You''''' know what you are doing, but nobody '''''ELSE''''' does."<ref name=brands/>
[[File:SitH - Hires Root Beer mug.jpg|thumb|left|Hires Root Beer mug, 1930s or earlier]] One of the major ingredients of root beer was [[sassafras]] oil, a plant root extract used in beverages for its flavor and presumed medicinal properties. The medicinal properties of root beer are emphasized in the advertising slogan, "Join Health and Cheer; Drink Hires Rootbeer." The U.S. [[Food and Drug Administration]] banned sassafras oil in 1960 because it contains the carcinogen and liver-damaging chemical [[safrol]]. However, a process was later discovered by which the harmful chemical could be removed from sassafras oil while preserving the flavor.<ref name=nickell>{{cite journal |last=Nickell |first=Joe |date=January‚ÄìFebruary 2011 |title='Pop' Culture: Patent Medicines Become Soft Drinks |journal=Skeptical Inquirer |volume=35 |issue=1 |pages=14‚Äì17 |publisher=[[Committee for Skeptical Inquiry]] |url=http://www.csicop.org/si/show/pop_culture_patent_medicines_become_soda_drinks |accessdate=2014-08-22}}</ref>
Prior to the move to "natural and artificial flavors", Hires ingredients included carbonated water, sugar, dextrose, caramel, plant extractives of birch, sassafras, licorice, vanilla, spikenard, sarsaparilla, hops, wintergreen, pipsissewa, ginger and flavor.
Hires Root Beer kits, available in the [[United States]] and Canada from the early 1900s through the 1980s allowed consumers to mix an extract with water, sugar and yeast to brew their own root beer. However, most consumption was of pre-bottled root beer.
A mid-1960s' advertising campaign featured jingles by jazz singer [[Blossom Dearie]], wherein she sang in a Betty-Boop voice: "Hires Root Beer! Hires Rootin' Tootin' Root Beer! Hires Rootin'-Tootin' Rabble-Rousin', lion-roarin', Roman-candle-lightin' Root Beer!"
== Today == [[Sara Lee Corporation|Consolidated Foods]] bought the company from the Hires family in 1960, only to sell Hires two years later to [[Crush (beverage)|Crush International]]. [[Procter & Gamble]] bought Crush in 1980, and sold it to [[Cadbury|Cadbury Schweppes]] in 1989. Cadbury divested its soft drinks arm in 2008, and the beverage company renamed itself Keurig Dr Pepper that year.
In Canada, the Hires brand is no longer sold by Keurig Dr Pepper; retailers and vending machines have replaced it with [[Pepsi]]-owned [[Mug Root Beer]] since the 1990s and DPSG markets Stewarts Root Beer in Canada. The Hires brand is now offered by [[Canada Dry Motts]] as an alcoholic drink, Hires Root Beer and Vodka.<ref name=rv>{{cite web| title=Hires Root Beer and Vodka| url=http://www.canadadrymotts.ca/brands/Hires| publisher=Canada Dry Motts| date=27 November 2018| accessdate=2018-11-27}}</ref>
Hires availability in the U.S. is limited as other Dr. Pepper owned brands like [[A&W Root Beer]] are competing for the same bottlers on behalf of the same company.<ref name=bp>{{cite web| title=Killing A Product ‚Äì The Demise of Hires Root Beer| url=http://stuffnobodycaresabout.com/2011/08/22/killing-a-product-why-you-cant-find-hires-root-beer/| publisher=Stuff Nobody Cares About| date=22 August 2011| accessdate=2014-08-22}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2018}} {{Use Australian English|date=November 2018}} [[File:Petrie Terrace Police, 1867.jpg|thumb|Police at Petrie Terrace, 1867]] The '''history of the Queensland Police Service''' in [[Queensland]], Australia, commenced in 1864, five years after the [[Separation of Queensland]] from [[New South Wales]] in 1859. This timeline highlights significant developments in Queensland policing.
{{toclimit|limit=2}}
== 1860s ==
=== 1864 === The [[Queensland Police Force]] was established by the [[Queensland Government]] on 1 January 1864 with strength of 287 officers serving a population of 61,467. [[David Thompson Seymour]] appointed as Acting Commissioner and later as Commissioner.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.police.qld.gov.au/aboutUs/facilities/museum/celebrate/history/timeline.htm|title=Policing Queensland Timeline 1864 - 2014|last=|first=|date=7 July 2017|website=|publisher=[[Queensland Police Museum]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181104070905/https://www.police.qld.gov.au/aboutUs/facilities/museum/celebrate/history/timeline.htm|archive-date=4 November 2018|dead-url=no|access-date=4 November 2018}}</ref>
The uniform worn by Queensland police officers after separation in 1859 was a dark blue jacket and top with a forage cap, supplied by the [[New South Wales Police Force|New South Wales police]].<ref name=":0" />
Transport in the settled areas was mainly by foot and in the unsettled areas by horse.<ref name=":0" />
The hulk ''Margaret Eliza'' was purchased for ¬£3000. It was refitted and renamed the ''Proserpine''. She was used as a floating water police office, prison, and later as a reformatory school.<ref name=":0" />
Correspondence with the Police Commissioner or between stations was by handwritten letter, moved by horse or [[Cobb & Co|Cobb and Co]] [[stagecoach]], or by [[Telegraphy|telegram]].<ref name=":0" />
Finding that no written instructions had ever been issued for the guidance of the police, Commissioner Seymour issues "Rules for the General Government and Discipline of members of the Police Force of Queensland" based upon the [[Victoria Police|Victorian police]] model.<ref name=":0" />
On 1 December, the Detective Office was created with Sub-Inspector George Elliott in charge.<ref name=":0" />
=== 1865 === Police Commissioner David Seymour described the lack of accommodation for police: "Many men are compelled to live in lodgings, and in the country districts constables live in public-houses some distance from the lock-up at times making them unavailable for sudden emergencies".<ref name=":0" />
Police Commissioner Seymour focussed on the crime of [[bushranging]] and took active measures to hasten the capture of these criminals through the purchase of fresh police horses and the construction of securely fenced paddocks at every police station.<ref name=":0" />
Water police were stationed on board the Hulk Proserpine at the mouth of the [[Brisbane River]].<ref name=":0" />
Revolvers were supplied to every police station and 50 [[Breechloading carbines|breech-loading carbines]] were delivered to the Department.<ref name=":0" />
=== 1866 === The [[Bread or Blood riot]] started, threatening the sacking of [[Old Government House, Queensland|Government House]] in [[Brisbane]]. Hundreds of government officials were sworn in as Special Constables to assist police.<ref name=":0" />
The first uniform consisted of a Garibaldi jacket of dark blue, serge wool cloth, red facings, and shoulder knot; trousers of the same material, with red cord, and a high cap with French peak.<ref name=":0" />
=== 1867 === On 6 November 1867 Constable Patrick William Cahill and Constable John Francis Power were poisoned and shot in the head at the [[Mackenzie River (Queensland)|MacKenzie River Crossing]] while escorting a consignment of bank notes and bullion from [[Rockhampton]] to [[Clermont, Queensland|Clermont]].<ref name=":5">{{Cite web|url=https://www.police.qld.gov.au/aboutUs/commemoration/honour/roll.htm|title=ROLL OF HONOUR 1867 - 1883|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=[[Queensland Police]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170601055253/https://www.police.qld.gov.au/aboutUs/commemoration/honour/roll.htm|archive-date=1 June 2017|dead-url=no|access-date=1 June 2017}}</ref> The first major test for the Detective Office was to solve their murders.<ref name=":0" />
Police Commissioner Seymour stated that "men at all stations are, when practicable, to be drilled once a week".<ref name=":0" />
=== 1869 === The publication of "Rules for the General Government and Discipline of members of the Police Force of Queensland" was approved, printed and distributed.<ref name=":0" />
Each constable required one pair of [[handcuffs]] as part of his equipment allotment.<ref name=":0" />
== 1870s ==
=== 1870 === A police barracks was established in [[George Street, Brisbane|George Street]], [[Brisbane]], on the site of the old convict hospital.<ref name=":0" />
Changes to rank insignia were implemented which among other things meant that an Acting Sergeant would be called a Senior Constable.<ref name=":0" />
=== 1872 === A general order was issued that the Chinese had as much right on the gold fields as Europeans, so long as they had a miners' permit. If a collision resulted in a riot which the police could not quell, they were to note the ring-leaders and apprehend them.<ref name=":0" />
=== 1873 === Sub-Inspector [[Robert Arthur Johnstone|Robert Johnstone]], officer in charge of native police, accompanied explorer [[George Elphinstone Dalrymple|George Dalrymple]] on the north-east coast expedition to explore the coastal lands as far as [[Cooktown, Queensland|Cooktown]].<ref name=":0" />
=== 1875 === The bulk of the Queensland Police force moved from the [[Brisbane CBD]] to [[Victoria Barracks, Brisbane|Victoria Barracks]] and occupies the army buildings on site.<ref name=":0" />
Three movable houses and twelve large frame-tents were built in Brisbane and shipped to the [[Palmer River Goldfields|Palmer River gold-field]]. They were quickly erected by two constables and could house six officers.<ref name=":0" />
=== 1876 === The Police Manual instructed constables on beat duty to "possess such knowledge of the inhabitants of each house as to enable them to recognise their persons; and thus prevent mistakes, and be enabled to render assistance, when called upon, to the inhabitants".<ref name=":0" />
"Instructions for the Guidance of the Police" were published and a system of competitive examination for promotion was introduced, intended to increase police efficiency.<ref name=":0" />
=== 1879 === Roma Street Police Barracks were built and provided accommodation for about forty-five men, room for an Officer-in-Charge and two cells.<ref name=":0" />
Navy blue helmets were introduced and proved to be a very hot choice of headwear; they were phased out in favour of white helmets in 1896.<ref name=":0" />
== 1880s ==
=== 1880 === At [[Birdsville]], locally-available [[Canegrass|cane grass]] was used on police station walls for its insulation properties and longevity.<ref name=":0" />
[[Native Police]] camp accommodation was constructed using a variety of materials, such as saplings, logs, bark, canvas and shingles.<ref name=":0" />
=== 1881 === On 24 January Sub-Inspector George Dyas was found buried after being killed by being speared in the back by [[Aboriginal Australians|Aboriginals]] while he camped near the 40 Mile Waterhole near [[Normanton, Queensland|Normanton]].<ref name=":5"/>
On 24 September Sub-Inspector Henry Kaye died from being speared through the chest by [[Aboriginal Australians|Aboriginals]] at Woolgar gold fields (100 km north of [[Richmond, Queensland|Richmond]]).<ref name=":5"/>
=== 1882 === Sub-Inspector 1/c Alexander Douglas was sent to [[Herberton, Queensland|Herberton]] and with four troopers, two old gold diggers and five Chinese men; he blazed a trail from Herberton to [[Mourilyan, Queensland|Mourilyan]]. The party travelled without rations and in continuous rain for twenty days, living mainly on roots.<ref name=":0" />
[[Martini-Henry Rifle|Martini-Henry rifles]] were purchased to replace the [[Snider Rifle|Snider]] previously used.<ref name=":0" />
=== 1883 === The [[Petrie Terrace Gaol]] area was taken over by the Queensland Police and became known as the [[Petrie Terrace Police Depot]] where prospective police officers were trained.<ref name=":0" />
On 24 January Cadet Sub-Inspector Mark Beresford died after being speared in the thigh and hit on the head by [[Aboriginal Australians|Aboriginals]] in the [[Selwyn Range (Australia)|Selwyn Ranges]] to the south of [[Cloncurry, Queensland|Cloncurry]].<ref name=":5"/>
On 26 January Constable William Dwyer was struck on the head by a tomahawk and killed by an [[Aboriginal Australians|Aboriginal]] near Juandah Station via [[Taroom]].<ref name=":5"/>
=== 1884 === Cap badges consisting of a separate district letter and number were issued and remained in use until 1906.<ref name=":0" />
=== 1886 === The first six camels arrived in Birdsville from India in poor condition and by July only four had survived. Despite these early setbacks camels proved useful, travelling hundreds of kilometres on duties such as collecting statistical returns.<ref name=":0" />
=== 1887 === The first honour given to any Queensland police officer was a [[Royal Humane Society of Australasia|Royal Humane Society]] Bronze Medal awarded to Constable James O"Brien for saving the life of a nine year old boy at [[Ipswich, Queensland|Ipswich]].<ref name=":0" />
During the [[Burketown]] cyclone on 5 March, Sergeant John Ferguson"s wife kept a lamp burning in the window of the courthouse and her beacon drew many people to the refuge during the storm.<ref name=":0" />
=== 1889 === A [[Royal Commission of Inquiry|Royal Commission of Enquiry]] into the Police Force proposed sweeping changes including that the control of the section of Water Police known as River Police was given back to the police Commissioner.<ref name=":0" />
The cost of buying ordinary clothing for plain clothes work was an extra burden that detectives had to meet out of their ordinary pay.<ref name=":0" />
There were eleven detectives on the pay-roll across the state. Seven in Brisbane, two in [[Townsville]], and one each in [[Normanton, Queensland|Normanton]] and [[Rockhampton]].<ref name=":0" />
On 27 October Senior Constable Alfred Wavell was shot and killed at Corinda (southwest of [[Burketown, Queensland|Burketown]]) by a man who had escaped from the Normanton lock-up.<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=https://www.police.qld.gov.au/aboutUs/commemoration/honour/roll02.htm|title=ROLL OF HONOUR 1889 - 1903|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=[[Queensland Police]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170601051751/https://www.police.qld.gov.au/aboutUs/commemoration/honour/roll02.htm|archive-date=1 June 2017|dead-url=no|access-date=1 June 2017}}</ref>
== 1890s ==
=== 1891 === Senior Sergeant Martin Breene and Constable Joseph Waters displayed energy and perseverance during the [[1891 Australian shearers' strike|shearer"s strikes]] by following and preventing "fire gangs" from doing damage at [[Lammermoor pastoral station]].<ref name=":0" />
=== 1893 === [[File:James Sangster Memorial, circa 1940.jpg|thumb|James Sangster Memorial, circa 1940]] During the shearer"s strike, police were given sole power to "preserve order and secure liberty to all alike".<ref name=":0" />
Acting Sergeant John Raphael Thompson was paid ¬£10 extra to attend to photographic work which included [[mug shot|mug shots]] and [[crime scene photography]].<ref name=":0" />
On 4 February Constable James Sangster, 25, drowned attempting a rescue of two members of the Jackson family during the [[1893 Brisbane flood|1893 flood]] of the [[Bremer River (Queensland)|Bremer River]] at [[North Ipswich, Queensland|North Ipswich]].<ref name=":4"/> He is commemorated by the [[James Sangster Memorial]] at North Ipswich, which was initiated by the Jackson family and funded by public subscription. The monument has a broken obelisk which symbolises a life cut short.<ref name="qhr2">{{cite QHR|21160|James Sangster Memorial|602581|accessdate=30 November 2018}}</ref>
=== 1894 === On 10 May Constable Benjamin Ebbitt died at [[South Brisbane, Queensland|South Brisbane]] having never recovered from an assault during an arrest on 9 November 1890 at [[Croydon, Queensland|Croydon]].<ref name=":4"/>
On 6 September Constable Edward Lanigan was killed by being shot in the chest while trying to prevent another policeman from being shot during an arrest at [[Montalbion, Queensland|Montalbion]] (a mining town near [[Irvinebank]]).<ref name=":4"/>
=== 1895 === On 30 June, Commissioner Seymour retired after 31 years in the job and was replaced by [[William Edward Parry-Okeden]] on 1 July. Full control of the water police finally came under the jurisdiction of Police Commissioner.<ref name=":0" />
On 2 July Senior Constable William Conroy died after being stabbed several times trying to prevent a man from stabbing the man's wife on [[Thursday Island]].<ref name=":4"/>
The Roma Street police station telephone exchange was connected to fourteen sites including the [[Woolloongabba Police Station|Woolloongabba]] and [[South Brisbane, Queensland|South Brisbane]] police stations, the Commissioners house at [[Red Hill, Queensland|Red Hill]], the Detective Office, the Police Depot and the [[Brisbane Central Fire Brigade Station|Central Fire Brigade Station]].<ref name=":0" />
=== 1896 === The bicycle, as a means of transport was introduced and a slow distribution occurred across the state. At about ¬£13 a bicycle was more expensive than a horse.<ref name=":0" />
Detectives received no special training. Generally, "the smartest and most intelligent' people from among the plain clothes officers in the general police were selected and expected to learn from experience.<ref name=":0" />
The [[Capsize of the ferry Pearl|Pearl ferry capsized]] near the [[Victoria Bridge, Brisbane|Victoria Bridge]] on the flooded Brisbane River on [[Valentine's Day]]. After the rescue of sixty survivors, police made every effort to recover and identify the bodies of the twenty-nine victims.<ref name=":0" />
A loose tunic was adopted in place of the existing jumper for police uniform. Mounted officers performing mounted duty, wore Bedford cord breeches and black napoleon boots.<ref name=":0" />
=== 1897 === The collection housed in the "[[Queensland Police Museum|Police Museum]]" running since 1893, was used to educate recruits about criminal methods.<ref name=":0" />
=== 1899 === On the trail of an escapee, Constable James Kenny and four indigenous troopers survived [[Cyclone Mahina]] at [[Bathurst Bay]], by staying together after their camp was blown away.<ref name=":0" />
The recruit probation period was increased so that no man was sworn until three months' drill and instruction was completed at the Police Depot.<ref name=":0" />
== 1900s ==
=== 1900 === At the turn of the century the Queensland Police Department had 845 police officers and 135 [[Aboriginal tracker|native trackers]] at 256 stations.<ref name=":0" />
=== 1901 === First-Class Constable George Pugh displayed discretion and bravery in the single-handed arrest of three men for the unlawful killing of cattle at the [[Jundah, Queensland|Jundah]] Opal Fields, and for taking them on foot, the twenty miles to Jundah police station.<ref name=":0" />
The Criminal Investigation Branch moved into the [[old St John's Cathedral]] synod building on the corner of [[Elizabeth Street, Brisbane|Elizabeth]] and George Streets.<ref name=":0" />
=== 1902 === The [[Imperial Service Order]] and [[Imperial Service Medal|Medal]] was established by [[Edward VII|King Edward]] for the administration and clerical staff of the Civil Service throughout the [[British Empire]] for long and meritorious service.<ref name=":0" />
On 30 MarchConstable George Doyle was shot while attempting to capture the [[Kenniff brothers]], who had a long history of stealing cattle and horses, in [[Upper Warrego]].<ref name=":4"/>
=== 1903 === In May the Bronze Medal of the Royal Humane Society was awarded to First-class Michael Becher, Inspector Percy Galbraith, Constables Charles Pinwill and William Ryan who risked their own lives to save the lives of others between 12 November 1889 and 15 January 1903.<ref name=":0" />
On 29 March Acting Sergeant David Johnston was killed by being hit on the head with an axe by a prisoner in the watchhouse at [[Mackay, Queensland|Mackay]].<ref name=":4"/>
=== 1904 === The Fingerprint Bureau was established. During the first year of operation 578 [[Fingerprint|fingerprints]] were taken and 226 came from other states.<ref name=":0" />
On 16 September 1Constable First Class Charles O'Kearney was knocked down and killed by a horse being deliberately ridden towards him in retaliation for an arrest in [[Laidley, Queensland|Laidley]].<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=https://www.police.qld.gov.au/aboutUs/commemoration/honour/roll03.htm|title=ROLL OF HONOUR 1904 - 1963|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=[[Queensland Police]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170601044802/https://www.police.qld.gov.au/aboutUs/commemoration/honour/roll03.htm|archive-date=1 June 2017|dead-url=no|access-date=1 June 2017}}</ref>
=== 1905 === [[William Geoffrey Cahill]] became the third Police Commissioner on 1 April 1905.<ref name=":0" />
On 23 December Constable Albert Price was stabbed and killed while making an arrest at [[Mackay, Queensland|Mackay]].<ref name=":3"/>
=== 1906 === [[File:Queensland Police Medal for Merit (obverse).jpg|thumb|Medal for Merit (obverse)]]On 27 September 1906: Sergeant Thomas Heaney died at [[South Brisbane, Queensland|South Brisbane]] from head fractures sustained when he was hit multiple times over the head with a metal bar during an arrest on 7 June 1905 at [[Woolloongabba]], Brisbane.<ref name=":3"/>[[File:Queensland Police Medal for Merit (reverse).jpg|thumb|Medal for Merit (reverse)]] On 4 October Police Commissioner Cahill announced the establishment of a Medal for Merit departmental award for police officers who displayed pre-eminent bravery on duty. The first two medals were awarded to Acting Sergeant John Hennessy and Constable Richard Runge on 12 October.<ref name=":0" />
Queensland police enforced the [[Infant Life Protection Act 1905|Infant Life Protection Act of 1905]] by checking the registration of births and the deaths of [[illegitimate children]].<ref name=":0" />
=== 1907 === The Patrol was the first motorised vessel used by the [[Brisbane Water Police]]. She was capable of {{Convert|8|knot|}}.<ref name=":0" />
Constable Charles Watson and a tracker followed suspected murderer J.W Patterson for 350 miles. They captured the fugitive but had very little food or water for the last 100 miles of the chase.<ref name=":0" />
A new Figure of 8 style handcuff was introduced.<ref name=":0" />
=== 1909 === A very fine {{Convert|78,000|acre||adj=on}} reserve called Rewan was proclaimed as a stud farm for breeding [[Police horse|police horses]]. The Woodford mares and foals as well as two purchased stallions, "Libertine" and "Mack" populated the reserve.<ref name=":0" />
Very few police stations have a typewriter and some officers use their own to complete reports and correspondence.<ref name=":0" />
The [[King's Police Medal|Kings Police Medal]] was instituted by King Edward VII on 7 July to be awarded to those officers of properly recognised police forces and fire brigades under the jurisdiction of the sovereign, who showed distinguished service and conspicuous devotion to duty, or who carried out heroic acts of courage. First awarded to Constable John Bourke on 29 August 1911.<ref name=":0" />
== 1910s ==
=== 1910 === Inspector White reported that nearly every station within a five mile radius of the centre of Brisbane was connected by telephone.<ref name=":0" />
Chief Inspector Urquhart favourably mentioned Constable Peter Hagarty of [[Finch Hatton, Queensland|Finch Hatton]]: "he is an exceptional good man in a rough place among a very rough class of people. He made seventy-one arrests single handed this year and is most highly spoken of by the respectable portion of the community".<ref name=":0" />
=== 1911 === First reference to the idea of women police was made by the [[National Council of Women of Queensland]].<ref name=":0" />
=== 1912 === The [[1912 Brisbane general strike]] started as a [[Trams in Brisbane|tramway]] strike but gains momentum with 20,000 or more people withholding their labour and brings industry to a standstill. Mass rallies see police numbers bolstered by the swearing in of 3,000 Special Constables.<ref name=":0" />
=== 1914 === Police stations serve a variety of local community needs and police officers were expected to act in extraneous roles as representatives for the government.<ref name=":0" />
=== 1915 === Police Commissioner Cahill rejects the idea of employing women following an enquiry by the Acting Home Secretary.<ref name=":0" />
=== 1916 === The strength of the Force on 30 June, was 1037 general police, 30 Criminal Investigation Branch officers, 11 water police officers, 99 indigenous police, 27 recruits and 89 on leave with the [[Australian Imperial Force (1st)|Commonwealth Military Forces]] on active service in [[World War I]].<ref name=":0" />
At 13 July, four year old Nicholas Frousheger wandered away from his home about three miles south of [[Charleville, Queensland|Charleville]]. The media reports that "the police, and a large party of civilians are trying hard to overtake him, but it is difficult owing to the stony ridges and the light imprint left by the little one".<ref name=":0" />
=== 1917 === [[Frederic Charles Urquhart]] becomes the fourth Police Commissioner on 1 January 1917.<ref name=":0" />
=== 1919 === On 24 March, 8,000 soldiers and conservatives march on the [[Russian √©migr√©s|Russian √©migr√©]] headquarters at [[South Brisbane, Queensland|South Brisbane]] which leads to violent clashes between protestors and police. This uprising was known as the [[Red Flag riots|Red Flag Riots]] or Red Monday.<ref name=":0" />
== 1920s ==
=== 1920 === Bicycles, not cars, were the usual means of transportation used by police for the prevention and detection of crime. Police Commissioner Ryan establishes bicycle patrols so that plain clothes officers could keep the suburbs of Brisbane under surveillance at night time.<ref name=":0" />
=== 1921 === An [[Mount Mulligan mine disaster|explosion at Mount Mulligan Colliery]] entombs over seventy miners. Residents, men from a neighbouring mine assist Constable James O"Dwyer in efforts to recover deceased miners.<ref name=":0" />
[[Patrick Short (police commissioner)|Patrick Short]] became the fifth Police Commissioner on 16 January 1921.<ref name=":0" />
=== 1924 === The first thorough revision of "Rules for the general government and discipline of the members of the Police Force of Queensland" was completed.<ref name=":0" />
=== 1925 === [[File:Queensland State Archives 929 Mr W H Ryan Commissioner of Police caught a fine Albacore Linne Passage c 1931.png|thumb|Police Commissioner, William Harold Ryan catches a fish in the Linne Passage, circa 1931]] 779 horses were in service, three camels were obtained for [[Noccundra]] police station and three new [[Harley-Davidson]] [[Motorcycle|motorcycles]] with [[Sidecar|side cars]] were purchased.<ref name=":0" />
[[William Harold Ryan]] becomes the sixth Police Commissioner on 15 January 1925.<ref name=":0" />
=== 1926 === The first two motorised vehicles were Black Marias or [[Prisoner transport vehicle|prison vans]], one of which utilised the body from a horse-drawn prison van on the back of a Bean truck chassis.<ref name=":0" />
=== 1927 === The Criminal Investigation Branch building in [[Queen's Park, Brisbane|Queen's Park,]] was blown up by a criminal intent on destroying the evidence against him.<ref name=":0" />
Retired Sergeant 2/c William Lynam had the gruesome job of burying seventeen [[Ingham, Queensland|Ingham]] flood victims, men, women, and children of three Italian families "on the nearest patch of dry land I could find".<ref name=":0" />
Dustcoats and overalls were worn by members of the Criminal Investigation Branch when riding on motorcycles to prevent dust and oil from staining clothing.<ref name=":0" />
=== 1928 === There was only one detective available to handle criminal investigations between Townsville and [[Cloncurry, Queensland|Cloncurry]].<ref name=":0" />
=== 1929 === Inspector Loch describec [[Cecil Plains, Queensland|Cecil Plains]] as "a large pastoral and farming district with large areas of thickly timbered and pear infested ground that gives stock thieves excellent opportunity to carry out their work.<ref name=":0" />
== 1930s == [[File:Constable Ernest Dawson and a cat at a camp near Ayr, circa 1930.jpg|thumb|Constable Ernest Dawson playing with a cat at a camp near [[Ayr, Queensland|Ayr]], circa 1930]]
=== 1930 === [[File:The funeral procession for Constable Ernest Dawson.jpg|thumb|Funeral procession for Constable Ernest Dawson, 1931]] On 6 August 1930 Constable Ernest James Dawson was on traffic duty on the Yungaburra Road near [[Lake Barrine]] when he lost control of his motorcycle. Despite emergency surgery which appeared initially successful, complications arose and he died in [[Brisbane General Hospital]] on 18 January 1931.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article180973699|title=CONSTABLE'S DEATH.|date=19 January 1931|newspaper=[[Daily Standard]]|accessdate=12 September 2018|issue=5620|location=Queensland, Australia|page=15|via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> There was a huge funeral procession in his honour on 19 January 1931.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://mypolice.qld.gov.au/museum/2018/09/11/from-the-vault-a-fitting-farewell/|title=From the Vault ‚Äì A Fitting Farewell|last=|first=|date=11 September 2018|website=|publisher=[[Queensland Police Museum]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180912031057/https://mypolice.qld.gov.au/museum/2018/09/11/from-the-vault-a-fitting-farewell/|archive-date=12 September 2018|dead-url=no|access-date=12 September 2018}}</ref>
=== 1931 === [[File:Zara Dare, one of the two first women appointed to the Queensland Police Force, 1931.jpg|thumb|Zara Dare, one of the first two women appointed to the Queensland Police Force, 1931]][[File:Policewoman Eileen O‚ÄôDonnell is pictured left and stands with three debutantes before they are presented to his Excellency the Governor Sir Leslie Wilson, at the first Queensland Police Ball, August 1, 1934.jpg|thumb|Policewoman Eileen O‚ÄôDonnell (left) with three debutantes at the first Queensland Police Ball, 1 August 1934]]The first two women police, Miss [[Zara Dare]] and Miss [[Eileen O'Donnell (police officer)|Eileen O'Donnell]] were appointed on 16 March, after [[Queensland Cabinet]] supported a submission by [[Irene Longman]], Queensland's first female Member of the [[Queensland Legislative Assembly]]. They were attached to Roma Street police station in the centre of Brisbane but were not sworn-in and had no powers of arrest. They did not have a uniform but were given a badge. Their duties were to protect the interests of women and children.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{cite news|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article180978803|title=Two Policewomen Appointed.|date=26 February 1931|newspaper=[[Daily Standard]]|accessdate=28 November 2018|issue=5653|location=Queensland, Australia|page=1|via=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
=== 1932 === On 5 January, four-year-old Betty Doherty was taken by {{Convert|4|m||adj=on}} crocodile as she plays near the [[Seymour River (Queensland)|Seymour River]], about twelve kilometres east of [[Halifax, Queensland|Halifax]]. Acting Sergeant Frank Conaty and Constables George Schnitzerling, Jens Fredericksen and Arnold Still made an extensive search but fail to find any trace of the child.<ref name=":0" />
=== 1934 === [[Cecil James Carroll]] becomes the seventh Police Commissioner on 8 May 1934.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{cite news|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article23335563|title=General|date=17 May 1934|newspaper=[[The Queenslander]]|accessdate=28 November 2018|location=Queensland, Australia|page=5|via=National Library of Australia}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article41241180|title=SURPRISE ANNOUNCEMENT.|date=11 January 1934|newspaper=[[Cairns Post]]|accessdate=28 November 2018|issue=9964|location=Queensland, Australia|page=6|via=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
A special squad of traffic police was organised for the control of the Brisbane traffic district.<ref name=":0" />
The [[Battley Single Finger Print System]] was adopted, to reduce the period of search for a print found at the crime scene among the 470,000 impressions held.<ref name=":0" />
Carroll introduces the police cadet system to admit applicants of 18 years with a junior pass or a senior level school certificate.<ref name=":0" /> [[File:The crowd of 2000 pose for a photograph at the inaugural Police Ball, Brisbane City Hall, 1 August 1934.jpg|thumb|Group photo, inaugural Police Ball, Brisbane City Hall, 1 August 1934]] Carroll initiated the establishment of the Queensland Police Welfare Club which was located within Roma Street police station and served alcohol as well as offering recreational amenties such as a library, [[Billiard table|billiard tables]] and [[Dart board|darts boards]]. Six weeks after its establishment the Club held its first ball at the [[Brisbane City Hall]] on 1 August 1934. Over 2,000 people attended and was believed to be the largest function of its kind ever held in Brisbane. The balls were an annual event and were held at Brisbane City Hall until the 1960s when they relocated to [[Cloudland|Cloudland Ballroom]]; the balls ceased in the 1970s.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://mypolice.qld.gov.au/museum/2018/09/18/from-the-vault-queensland-police-ball-1934/|title=FROM the VAULT ‚Äì Queensland Police Ball, 1934|last=|first=|date=18 September 2018|website=[[Queensland Police Museum]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181129191825/https://mypolice.qld.gov.au/museum/2018/09/18/from-the-vault-queensland-police-ball-1934/|archive-date=30 November 2018|dead-url=no|access-date=30 November 2018}}</ref>
=== 1935 === The [[Modus operandi|Modus Operandi]] Section was established by Police Commissioner Carroll as a central repository for criminal records regarding their habits or manner of working. A Criminal Photographic Supplement was reproduced in the [[Queensland Police Gazette]] to allow quick access to the information collected by the Modus Operandi Section.<ref name=":0" />
The Queensland Police Department was given control of the Firearms Act and creates the Firearms Section under Clerk Thomas Baty, to undertake the major task of licensing firearms.<ref name=":0" />
Commissioner Carroll gains approval for an experimental wireless station with the call sign VKR. Three patrol cars were equipped with the new one-way, wireless communication system.<ref name=":0" />
Weekly lectures were delivered by experienced officers at the Roma Street police barracks and copies of lectures were distributed to every police officer.<ref name=":0" />
=== 1936 === Newly sworn Constable Thomas Baty assumes charge of the Firearm Section.<ref name=":0" />
The new brick two-storey, [[Fortitude Valley Police Station|Fortitude Valley police station]] was built and officially opened on 6 July. It was described as the "finest, most up-to-date and most comfortable police station in Queensland".<ref name=":0" /> It is now heritage-listed.<ref name="qhr">{{cite QHR|15935|Fortitude Valley Police Station|601168|accessdate=1 August 2014}}</ref>
=== 1937 === The Queensland Police becomes mechanised and a departmental garage was built to service the departments growing number of motorcycles and motor vehicles. Trained mechanics worked in the garage.<ref name=":0" />
The Firearms Section was enlarged to include [[forensic ballistics]] and a laboratory was installed, with [[Microscopy|microscopical]] and [[Photomicrograph|photomicrographical]] apparatus to examine bullets.<ref name=":0" />
A librarian was appointed to look after the Central Police Library's collection of 5,000 law, crime and fiction books.<ref name=":0" />
=== 1938 === The Criminal Investigation Branch consisted of 48 detectives, 65 plain clothes police spread over all districts, along with 14 cadets.<ref name=":0" />
The Firearm Section was expanded to encompass the scientific investigation of firearms under the area of Forensic Ballistics.<ref name=":0" />
On 28 November Constable George Robert Young of the water police was one of four men on a [[RAAF]] amphibious aircraft which crashed killing all on board. They were searching for the body of missing woman Marjorie Norval in the estuaries of [[Moreton Bay]] when the aircraft hit high tension wires.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article71359321|title=TERRIBLE QUEENSLAND AIR DISASTER|date=29 November 1938|newspaper=[[Worker]]|accessdate=12 September 2018|issue=2682|location=Queensland, Australia|volume=49,|page=28|via=National Library of Australia}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://mypolice.qld.gov.au/museum/2013/10/22/from-the-vault-the-death-of-constable-george-young-1938/|title=FROM the VAULT ‚Äì The death of Constable George Young, 1938|last=|first=|date=22 October 2013|website=|publisher=Queensland Police Service|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180912044327/https://mypolice.qld.gov.au/museum/2013/10/22/from-the-vault-the-death-of-constable-george-young-1938/|archive-date=12 September 2018|dead-url=no|access-date=12 September 2018}}</ref>
=== 1939 === During [[World War II]] (1939 to 1945) the Police Commissioner worked in co-operation with the [[Australian Defence Department]] to provide protection of civilian lives, public buildings and communications lines.<ref name=":0" />
=== 1939 === The Kings Commendation for Brave Conduct was instituted by [[King George VI]] to acknowledge brave acts by civilians and members of the military in non-warlike circumstances during a time of war or in peacetime where the action would not otherwise be recognised by an existing award.<ref name=":0" />
Legislation provides police with selection of and control over civilian [[Air Raid Warden|air-raid wardens]]. Police officers were involved in enrolling and training wardens to receive and pass on news of raids from Defence Information Centres.<ref name=":0" />
A seven-month-long "School of Instruction in Criminal Investigation Work" course was established.<ref name=":0" />
New barracks at Petrie Terrace were built to replace the old structure used since 1883 at a cost of ¬£40,000. It provided a training centre for recruits and a home for 104 single men performing duty in central Brisbane.<ref name=":0" />
== 1940s ==
=== 1940 === The system of interchange of detectives and the sharing of knowledge with New South Wales and Victoria police continues, with one Queensland detective working in Sydney and the other in Melbourne.<ref name=":0" />
The Kings Police Medal becomes The Kings Police and Fire Services Medal and was awarded for acts of exceptional courage and skill or who exhibit conspicuous devotion to duty. First awarded to Constable Athol Haines on 28 July 1943.<ref name=":0" />
The [[George Medal]] was established by order of [[King George VI]] on 4 September, was given for acts of great bravery. First awarded to Constable 1/c Osmond Cislowski on 11 May 1956.<ref name=":0" />The number of women in the Women Police Section increases to nine in response to the extra demands on policing during World War II.<ref name=":0" />
=== 1941 === A permanent [[two-way radio]] station, allowing two-way radio wireless communication with patrol cars, was established to replace the temporary one-way system in use since 1935.<ref name=":0" />
The Women Police Section was formed with Elizabeth Boyle as Supervisor and attached to the Criminal Investigation Branch Headquarters in George Street Brisbane.<ref name=":0" />
The [[Central Fingerprint Bureau]] in Sydney was created for use by all policing jurisdictions.<ref name=":0" />
The Forensic Ballistics Section was renamed as the Scientific Section and now encompasses [[forensic chemistry]], scientific photography and the [[Questioned document examination|examination of documents and handwriting]]. The Scientific Section was examining documents and handwriting with [[Ultraviolet|ultra-violet rays]] and [[microscopy]].<ref name=":0" />
The Force was staffed by 1610 sworn police and 34 [[Aboriginal tracker|native trackers]] at 341 stations.<ref name=":0" />
=== 1942 === Inspector Noel Carseldine remarked: "The fact of the war having continued throughout the year has meant the performance of arduous duties by the police in this district.
