Several hundred aliens have been interned in the sugar areas of [[Ayr]], [[Brandon, Queensland|Brandon]], [[Giru, Queensland|Giru]], [[Halifax, Queensland|Halifax]], [[Home Hill, Queensland|Home Hill]] and [[Ingham, Queensland|Ingham]]".<ref name=":0" />
=== 1945 === 246 bicycles were in use across the state.<ref name=":0" />
The Fingerprint Bureau, the Modus Operandi Record System, the Photographic and Scientific Sections were classified under the title: Technical Aids in the Investigation of Crime.<ref name=":0" />
=== 1946 === Detective Constable Les Bardwell took over the Scientific Section and remains as the Officer in Charge until his retirement in 1976.<ref name=":0" />
The "White Ghost", a white Chevrolet Special Deluxe utility, equipped with a loud hailer, was introduced to Brisbane and Toowoomba streets as part of a [[road safety]] campaign.<ref name=":0" />
New uniform consisted of an open-neck tunic, airman's blue shirt, with detachable collar, black tie, and a new type white helmet.<ref name=":0" /> === 1947 === The Photographic Unit gains staff who have experience with drawing plans of [[Crime scene|crime scenes]] and [[Road collision types|road collisions]].<ref name=":0" />
Probationaries undergo six months of training at the Police Depot.<ref name=":0" /> === 1948 === The [[Queensland Police-Citizens Youth Welfare Association]] was registered under the jurisdiction of the Police Department on 20 May.<ref name=":0" /> === 1949 === There were 100 cars in use across the state representing brands such as [[Ford Motor Company|Ford]], [[Buick]], [[Chevrolet]], [[International Motors Company|International]], [[GMC (automobile)|G.M.C]], [[Mercury (automobile)|Mercury]], [[Hudson Motor Car Company|Hudson]], [[DeSoto (automobile)|De Soto]], [[Dodge]] and [[Plymouth (automobile)|Plymouth]].<ref name=":0" />
Fingerprint Expert Cecil Smith and two Queensland Detectives make history when they take hand and palm prints from almost the entire population of Ocean Island (now [[Banaba Island]]) to catch a double murderer.<ref name=":0" />
[[John Smith (police commissioner)|John Smith]] becomes the eight Police Commissioner on 24 July 1949.<ref name=":0" />
== 1950s ==
=== 1950 === Radio transmissions were made from [[Mount Coot-tha (Queensland)|Mount Coot-tha]] and the switch from [[Amplitude modulation|amplitude modulated]] (A.M.) mobile equipment to [[Frequency modulation|frequency modulated]] (F.M.) equipment was made.<ref name=":0" />
Road safety lectures were introduced into schools and kindergartens. Puppets were used to illustrate scenarios for younger children and older children were taught to cross the street and to ride a bicycle safely.<ref name=":0" />
After an inquisitive cow fell into a ditch at the rear of the [[Queensland Woollen Manufacturing Company mill|Queensland Woollen Mill]] in [[Ipswich, Queensland|Ipswich]], police were called to perform a rescue operation. Using a small crane, the heavy beast was successfully winched from the ditch and suffered only shock.<ref name=":0" />
There were fourteen police districts and 338 stations throughout Queensland at 30 June. [[Somerset, Queensland|Somerset]] police station was re-established and a new station was opened at [[Kenilworth, Queensland|Kenilworth]].<ref name=":0" />
The Police Force was staffed by 2030 sworn personnel, 10 women police and 30 trackers. The State population had reached one million.<ref name=":0" /> === 1951 === The Central Communications Room opens at the CIB building in Brisbane and becomes the nerve centre of police communications through the state.<ref name=":0" /> === 1954 === Police radio stations were operating in Brisbane, Rockhampton and Townsville.<ref name=":0" />
The [[British Empire Medal]] for Meritorious Service originally established in 1922, was first awarded to Constable Noel Haupt on 17 October.<ref name=":0" />
The [[King's Police and Fire Services Medal|Kings Police and Fire Services Medal]] was split into two awards, the [[Queen's Fire Service Medal|Queens Fire Service Medal]] and the [[Queen‚Äôs Police Medal for Gallantry|Queens Police Medal for Gallantry]] which was first awarded posthumously to Constable 1/c Roy Doyle on 1 April 1956.<ref name=":0" />
The [[King's Commendation for Brave Conduct|Kings Commendation for Brave Conduct]] became the [[Queen's Commendation for Brave Conduct|Queens Commendation for Brave Conduct]]. It was first awarded to Constable Clifford Lebsanft on 11 May 1956.<ref name=":0" /> === 1955 === Women were permitted to join the [[Queensland Police Union]].<ref name=":0" />
The Brisbane Traffic Branch was established as an entity separate from the Brisbane Police District.<ref name=":0" />
[[Patrick Glynn (police commissioner)|Patrick Glynn]] becomes the ninth Police Commissioner on 6 January 1955.<ref name=":0" /> === 1956 === The Union's application for equal pay fails in the Industrial Court.<ref name=":0" />
The state was affected by cyclonic disturbances and flood conditions resulting in widespread interruption to communications and damage to property.<ref name=":0" />
On 1 April Constable First Class Roy Doyle died in hospital at [[Mackay, Queensland|Mackay]] from head injuries sustained when he hit a submerged block of concrete while attempting a rescue in the flooded [[Pioneer River]] at [[Mackay, Queensland|Mackay]] on 29 March.<ref name=":3"/>
On 1 May the awarding of the [[Police Long Service and Good Conduct Medal]], originally proclaimed by [[King George VI]] in 1951, was extended to include the states of Australia by [[Elizabeth II|Queen Elizabeth II]]. The medal was awarded after twenty-two years of approved police service and 378 police officers qualify.<ref name=":0" /> === 1957 === 208 centres were sharing 384 vehicles and 126 horses ‚Äì 73 cars, 113 utilities, 37 land rovers, 6 vans, 155 motorbikes and 179 bicycles.<ref name=":0" />
[[Thomas William Harold]] becomes the tenth Police Commissioner on 1 April 1957.<ref name=":0" />
Two Traffic Branch officers attend the "Traffic Engineering Course" offered by the [[New South Wales University of Technology]].<ref name=":0" />
Police Commissioner Harold puts into operation four radio-equipped prowl cars to cruise the city and suburbs through the night.<ref name=":0" />
=== 1958 === [[File:Bischof in July 1962.jpg|thumb|Frank Bischof, 1962]] The [[British Empire Medal for Gallantry]] was established on 14 January. First awarded to Constable James Boyle on 7 August 1959.<ref name=":0" />
[[Frank Bischof|Francis Erich (Frank) Bischof]] becomes the eleventh Police Commissioner on 30 January 1958. With a view to raising the morale and status of newly sworn-in personnel, Bischof decides to inaugurate [[Passing out parade|Passing Out Parades]] for Probationaries. The first parade was held on 29 May with twenty-four men being sworn.<ref name=":0" />
The [[Queensland Police Pipe Band]] makes its first public appearance on 29 August at a passing out parade at the Petrie Terrace Police Depot.<ref name=":0" /> [[File:Police Pipe Band at Wooroolin (probably attending the Wooroolin ‚Äì Tingoora R.S.L. Highland Gathering and Sports Day), 1961.webp|thumb|Queensland Police Pipe Band at [[Wooroolin, Queensland|Wooroolin]] near [[Kingaroy]] 1961]]
=== 1959 === The Stock Investigation Squad was formed, with a detective sergeant and three plainclothes members.<ref name=":0" />
Sub-Inspector Cecil Smith was appointed as the first Queensland Police Public Relations Officer on 6 July. He was expected to make regular telecasts on topical police matters by way of the new technology of television.<ref name=":0" />
== 1960s ==
=== 1960 === Detective Senior Sergeant Les Bardwell, Constable Barry Short and Cadet Neil Raward were the only three scientific officers servicing the state.<ref name=":0" />
A new range of drab olive uniform and a new cap badge were introduced.<ref name=":0" />
=== 1961 === A new insignia was introduced which was an adaptation of the police badge. It bears the Latin motto "''Constantia ac Comitate"'' (English translation: Firmness with Courtesy'')''.<ref name=":0" />
=== 1962 === The old Queensland Egg Board building, on the corner of Makerston Street and North Quay was purchased and converted into a Police Headquarters.<ref name=":0" />
[[.38 Smith & Wesson|.38 Smith and Wesson revolvers]] were purchased to enable the standardisation of firearms.<ref name=":0" />
On 19 February Constable Gregory Olive was shot in the chest at close range when he knocked on a front door to make inquiries at [[Kelvin Grove, Queensland|Kelvin Grove]], Brisbane.<ref name=":3"/>
On 16 August Constable Douglas Wrembeck stopped to question a motorist in [[South Brisbane, Queensland|South Brisbane]] and was killed when he was struck by a car driven by a [[Hit and run|hit-and-run]] driver.<ref name=":3"/>
=== 1963 === The Juvenile Aid Bureau was established to guide potential youthful law breakers on the right path and prevent them from incurring a court conviction.<ref name=":0" />
On 14 February Senior Constable Cecil Bagley was electrocuted when he tried to rescue a neighbour being electrocuted in his car at [[Mount Gravatt, Queensland|Mount Gravatt]], south Brisbane. Although at home, his death was deemed to have occurred while on duty because, as a police officer, he was always expected to respond in an emergency situation.<ref name=":3"/>
=== 1964 === On 30 June the police strength equals 2760 police officers (1 police officer to 571 people).<ref name=":0" />
On 26 October Senior Constable Desmond Trannore was shot attending a [[Domestic dispute|domestic disturbance]] near [[Gordonvale]], [[North Queensland]].<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=https://www.police.qld.gov.au/aboutUs/commemoration/honour/roll04.htm|title=ROLL OF HONOUR 1964 - 1987|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=[[Queensland Police]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170601044201/https://www.police.qld.gov.au/aboutUs/commemoration/honour/roll05.htmv|archive-date=1 June 2017|dead-url=no|access-date=1 June 2017}}</ref>
=== 1965 === On 31 March, eight serving plainclothes women police were sworn in and given equal powers and rank as male officers. In June the first uniformed women were sworn in following regular probationary training.<ref name=":0" />
Twenty-one new [[Ford Cortina|Cortina sedans]] were purchased for traffic work.<ref name=":0" />
179 cars, eight vans, eighteen motor cycles, one bus and one utility truck were fitted with two-way wireless. Twenty-three cars and three utility trucks were fitted with two-way wireless.<ref name=":0" />
The first set of specially chosen police was trained for a "Rescue 8" Squad to handle major incidents and disaster emergencies.<ref name=":0" />
The first ever issue of attire for policewomen was a female version of the drab olive uniform.<ref name=":0" />
=== 1966 === Sergeant 2/c Colin Ward and Constable Colin Tapsall installed the first police-owned [[Uhf radio|UHF radio]] linking system from [[Saddle Mountain (Queensland)|Saddle Mountain]] near [[Kuranda, Queensland|Kuranda]], to the [[Cairns Airport]].<ref name=":0" />
=== 1968 === All new CIB Detective appointees were required to attend a course of training that includes lectures by senior experienced detectives, films and practical application.<ref name=":0" />
The Company Squad was reorganised as the Fraud Squad.<ref name=":0" />
On 27 March Constable Douglas Gordon was shot and killed attending a [[Domestic dispute|domestic disturbance]] at [[Inala, Queensland|Inala]], in south Brisbane.<ref name=":2"/>
On 26 June the Crime Prevention Bureau commences operation, for the purpose of providing two police officers in a full-time capacity to impart security and personal safety advice to community members.<ref name=":0" />
The Emergency Squad was established principally to deal with the apprehension of armed offenders.<ref name=":0" />
A World War II [[sea mine]] washes up onto the beach at [[Surfers Paradise, Queensland|Surfers Paradise]], shocking those enjoying the sun, sand and surf. The device was successfully deactivated and removed by the [[Royal Australian Navy]] with the help of Gold Coast police.<ref name=":0" />
=== 1969 === Printing of Volume 1 of the new "Queensland Policeman's Manual" was completed and preparation of Volume 2 was well advanced.<ref name=":0" />
Probationaries receive training in the use of [[Breath testing|Breath Testing Devices]] (Alcotest) and Breath Analysing Instruments ([[Breathalyzer|Breathalyser]]).<ref name=":0" />
[[Norwin William Bauer]] becomes the twelfth Police Commissioner on 14 February.<ref name=":0" />
On 9 April Senior Constable Colin Brown was shot and killed while investigating the behaviour of a farm employee on a property near [[Dayboro]], north of Brisbane.<ref name=":2"/>
== 1970s ==
=== 1970 === The number of policewomen equals twenty-seven. Postings extend outside central Brisbane and to provincial centres.<ref name=":0" /> The Queensland Police Union achieves equal pay for women with the support of Police Commissioner [[Ray Whitrod]].<ref name=":0" />
The position of Assistant Commissioner (Crime) was established.<ref name=":0" />
The [[Chelmer Police College|Queensland Police College at Chelmer]] commences operation on 27 January as an "in-service training centre".<ref name=":0" />
All newly-sworn Constables were sent, over a period of twelve months, to different metropolitan police stations for on-the-job training.<ref name=":0" />
[[Raymond Wells Whitrod]] becomes the thirteenth Police Commissioner on 1 September 1970.<ref name=":0" />
=== 1971 === Police and protestors clash over the [[South Africa national rugby union team|South African Springbok football team's]] tour of Queensland.<ref name=":0" />
The minimum height for women joining was set at 162.5cm and the bar on married women joining up was removed.<ref name=":0" />
Consideration was given to the use of computers for police purposes.<ref name=":0" />
The Public Order Squad was formed with approximately 100 members, who provide staff for duty in connection with [[street demonstrations]] and similar disturbances.<ref name=":0" />
A new cadet training scheme was introduced. The three year structure, combines senior examination subjects and special police courses.<ref name=":0" />
The Police Driver Training Wing was established and courses commence on 1 March.<ref name=":0" />
Stage 1 of the [[Queensland Police Academy]] at [[Oxley, Queensland|Oxley]] opens in January and the first 150 cadets were admitted.<ref name=":0" />
Uniform colour changes from drab olive back to blue. Policewomen wear a black skirt, white shirt with black tie and bowler style cap.<ref name=":0" />
=== 1972 === The Queensland Police Academy officially opens at Oxley on 24 March.<ref name=":0" />
=== 1973 === A Crime Intelligence course for Detectives commences at the Chelmer Police College.<ref name=":0" />
=== 1974 === Two days after [[Cyclone Tracy]] devastates [[Darwin, Northern Territory|Darwin]] in the [[Northern Territory]], twelve Queensland police officers arrive to lend a hand.<ref name=":0" />
A [[Scenes of crime officer|Scenes of Crime]] Training Unit was opened at the Oxley Police Academy and a Scenes of Crime Unit becomes operational.<ref name=":0" />
First female detective was appointed.<ref name=":0" />
=== 1975 === [[File:Star of Courage.jpg|thumb|Star of Courage]] The Police Air Wing was established with the purchase of two [[Cessna 180|Cessna 180E]] aircraft. Four police officers and qualified pilots were attached to the Wing.<ref name=":0" />
The Rape Squad, comprising seven female constables, commences working from within the Information Bureau.<ref name=":0" />
The quota system for the recruitment of women was removed and integration was adopted in deployment. Police Commissioner Whitrod's open door policy results in an influx of women.<ref name=":0" />
Final year Cadets and Probationaries receive twenty-three training periods in crowd control, prisoner control and crisis-situation handling.<ref name=":0" />
The [[Star of Courage (Australia)|Star of Courage]], the second highest Australian bravery decoration, was established in the [[Australian honours system]] in February. It is awarded for acts of conspicuous courage in circumstances of great peril. Only four have been awarded to Queensland police officers, the first to Constable Rodney Edward on 16 March 1988.<ref name=":0" />
A new system of identification numbers and rank boards with metal chevrons were introduced for all ranks.<ref name=":0" />
On 2 November Senior Constable Lyle Hoey died after being deliberately run down by a car near [[Mount Molloy]] in [[North Queensland]].<ref name=":2"/>
=== 1976 === The number of Queensland policewomen equals 308.<ref name=":0" />
All police centres across the state have access to a motor vehicle.<ref name=":0" />
The Electronic Data Processing Unit was reorganised into the Planning and Research Branch and begins developing computer programs to make information available on criminal statistics, stolen vehicles, staff deployment, and vehicles of interest.<ref name=":0" />
Forbes House in Makerston Street was purchased and converted into Police Headquarters and officially opens 7 March.<ref name=":0" />
[[Terence Murray Lewis|Terence Murray (Terry) Lewis]] becomes the fourteenth Police Commissioner on 29 November 1976.<ref name=":0" />
=== 1977 === Three new police vessels were commissioned: ''D.G. Gordon'', ''G.J. Olive'' and ''Lyle M. Hoey''.<ref name=":0" /> They were named after three police officers who were killed in the line of duty.
The first step was taken in the automation of the colour printing process for the Photographic Section.<ref name=":0" />
Experienced journalist Ian Hatcher was appointed as the first Police Press Officer on 29 August. His responsibilities were to liaise with media and to publicise the work and improve the public image of the Force throughout the State.<ref name=":0" />
In January, Police pilot Sergeant 2/c Ron Rooke successfully carries out flood relief operations in the [[Camooweal]], [[Burketown]], Hamilton, [[Boulia, Queensland|Boulia]] and [[Doomadgee, Queensland|Doomadgee]] areas by dropping several hundred kilograms of food to stranded motorists.<ref name=":0" />
=== 1978 === The recruitment of female cadets was stopped but the quota for the recruitment of female adult probationers was revived.<ref name=":0" />
A computer systems training officer was appointed to train police officers in the correct use and operation of computer equipment for practical police work.<ref name=":0" />
=== 1979 === To give the public and the police an appreciation of the history of the Police Force, the Police Museum was fully open to the public on 17 May.<ref name=":0" />
On 12 March the Bomb Squad was reorganised as a two man Arson-Bomb Squad and its activities were expanded.<ref name=":0" />
An armed man hijacked a commercial aircraft between [[Coolangatta Airport|Coolangatta]] and Brisbane and holds air crew and passengers hostage at [[Eagle Farm Airport]]. Emergency Squad personnel were deployed while a police negotiator secures the release of the hostages.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{cite news|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article110950923|title=T.A.A. HOSTESS, CREW OVERPOWER MAN Aircraft hijack attempt foiled|date=9 June 1979|newspaper=[[The Canberra Times]]|accessdate=5 November 2018|issue=15,965|location=Australian Capital Territory, Australia|volume=53,|page=1|via=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
Epaulette boards give way to shoulder patches and stripes of rank on the sleeves of new uniform. The Latin motto adopted on the shoulder patches was "''Constantia Ac Comitate''".<ref name=":0" />
== 1980s ==
=== 1980 === A new computerised message-switching system was introduced, with terminals installed in the metropolitan area and some district headquarters.<ref name=":0" />
Traffic branch motorcyclists were issued with blue leather caps which were worn instead of helmets while off their bikes and directing traffic.<ref name=":0" />
=== 1981 === The Rescue Squad was created within the Task Force in Brisbane. Members were trained in all types of rescue situations so that they could assist in bringing aid to people beset by accidents or disasters.<ref name=":0" />
=== 1982 === A new American Style highway patrol was formed to operate on country highways in an effort to cut down the road toll. The patrol fleet was equipped with 53 V8 Falcons with long range radios, as well as 84 Yamaha four cylinder 1100cc road motorcycles.<ref name=":0" />
=== 1983 === The first Blood Splash Pattern Evaluation Course was held.<ref name=":0" />
The Explosive Ordinance Reconnaissance Team was established which took the responsibility for bomb response from the Arson and Bomb Squad.<ref name=":0" />
The Latin motto on shoulder patches was replaced by the English translation of "Firmness With Courtesy".<ref name=":0" />
=== 1984 === The Police Department's own computer system comes online and ends the shared arrangements with other government departments.<ref name=":0" />
The Safety House program commences and provides a safe place for children in the event they feel threatened.<ref name=":0" />
Rain and mud hamper police attempts to remove protestors trying to prevent the construction of the [[Cape Tribulation, Queensland|Cape Tribulation]] to [[Bloomfield, Queensland|Bloomfield]] Road.<ref name=":0" />
On 29 February Constable Michael Low was shot and killed attending a [[domestic dispute]] at [[Rockhampton|North Rockhampton]], [[Central Queensland]].<ref name=":2"/>
On 22 June Queensland motorcycle police establish the [[Guinness Book of Records]] world record for the number of riders on a motorcycle, when 35 police officers balance on a motorbike at [[Surfers Paradise Raceway]].<ref name=":0" />
=== 1985 === The Queensland police computer links to the Main Roads Department and the New South Wales police computer to increase access to information such as national stolen vehicles files.<ref name=":0" />
Adopt‚Äìa‚ÄìCop was introduced at Northgate State School, with Constable Michael Volk from Nundah Police Station eager to attend the school during lunch times to provide advice on road safety, bike safety and stranger danger.<ref name=":0" />
Long batons were purchased for use by members of Brisbane Mobile Patrols and the Brisbane Traffic Branch.<ref name=":0" />
=== 1986 === Queensland Police were officially linked to a central Finger-print Bureau in Sydney, which gives computer access to millions of prints throughout Australia and overseas.<ref name=":0" />
The Department operates 1,092 vehicles.<ref name=":0" />
There were 309 computer terminals in 121 locations. Training in computers was offered to Cadets and Probationaries at the Police Academy.<ref name=":0" />[[File:The Induction photo taken of Constable Peter Kidd, 1977, later killed on duty on 29 July 1987.jpg|thumb|Induction photo taken of Constable Peter Kidd, 1977, killed on duty on 29 July 1987]] === 1987 === [[File:Hundreds of police march in the funeral procession for Senior Constable Peter Kidd, 31 July 1987.jpg|thumb|Hundreds of police march in the funeral procession for Senior Constable Peter Kidd, 31 July 1987]] Under Police Commissioner Lewis the advancement of women was curtailed in most areas. The number of female sworn officers drops from over 8 per cent to 5 per cent.<ref name=":0" />
The Transport, Radio and Electronics Sections, Brisbane Mobile Patrols, and Traffic Accident Investigation Squad relocate to Alderley from the Petrie Terrace Police Depot.<ref name=":0" />
On 27 July the Fitzgerald Enquiry opens. It was a much needed, but painful organisational reform for the Queensland Police. Over the two years of the enquiry there were 238 hearings and 339 witnesses were called to give evidence.<ref name=":0" />
On 29 July Senior Constable Peter Grahame John Kidd was shot and killed in a raid at [[Virginia, Queensland|Virginia]], in north Brisbane. The raid was to recapture an extremely dangerous escapee from [[Long Bay Correctional Centre|Long Bay Jail]] who had subsequently committed several armed robberies. Kidd was the first member of the Tactical Response Team to enter the house. Having been shot through a closed door, Kidd continued to push through the door and returned fire. He then collapsed and died in hospital. Hundreds of police marched in Kidd's funeral procession held on 31 July. He was posthumously awarded the Queensland Police Valour Medal and the [[Star of Courage (Australia)|Star of Courage]].<ref name=":2"/><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://mypolice.qld.gov.au/museum/2017/07/18/vault-30th-anniversary-death-senior-constable-peter-kidd/|title=FROM the VAULT ‚Äì 30th Anniversary of the death of Senior Constable Peter Kidd|last=|first=|date=18 July 2017|website=[[Queensland Police Museum]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181130145201/https://mypolice.qld.gov.au/museum/2017/07/18/vault-30th-anniversary-death-senior-constable-peter-kidd/|archive-date=1 December 2018|dead-url=no|access-date=1 December 2018}}</ref>
On 21 September Ronald James Redmond becomes the Acting Police Commissioner.<ref name=":0" />
=== 1988 === The [[Neighborhood watch|Neighbourhood Watch Unit]] commences operation on 22 February after a successful pilot program conducted on the [[Gold Coast, Queensland|Gold Coast]]. The program aims to reduce preventable crimes, improve personal and household security, reduce fear of crime, and provide support for victims of crime.<ref name=":0" /> === 1989 === Crime Stoppers was established. Its role is to gather information from the community that will lead to offenders being caught and prosecuted.<ref name=":0" />
The first official video recording of a crime scene was conducted by the Photographic Section.<ref name=":0" />
On 29 June Constable Brett Handran was shot and killed attending a [[domestic dispute]] in [[Wynnum]], in east Brisbane.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.police.qld.gov.au/aboutUs/commemoration/honour/roll05.htm|title=ROLL OF HONOUR 1989 - 2011|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=[[Queensland Police]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170601043606/https://www.police.qld.gov.au/aboutUs/commemoration/honour/roll05.htm|archive-date=1 June 2017|dead-url=no|access-date=1 June 2017}}</ref>
Noel Newnham becomes sixteenth Police Commissioner on 1 November 1989.<ref name=":0" />
== 1990s ==
=== 1990 === Fitzgerald Enquiry recommendations augment the change from the Queensland Police Force to Queensland Police Service. A new badge was designed and the motto "With Honour We Serve" was approved.<ref name=":0" />
The first five female Inspectors were appointed.<ref name=":0" />
In May the Task Force was created in response to Fitzgerald Report recommendations. Its role was to support all regional commands through intelligence and co-ordination of crime operations.<ref name=":0" />
COMFIT, the electronic composition of faces from witness descriptions was developed by the Photographic Section.<ref name=":0" />
The Fingerprint Bureau, Photographic and Scientific Sections move to the 4th floor of the new headquarters building under the umbrella of the Forensic Services Branch.<ref name=":0" />
The new Police Communications Centre benefits from a two-million-dollar ESCORT Computer Aided Dispatch system that feeds instant information to mobile vehicles and foot patrols.<ref name=":0" />
The Queensland Police Service Valour Award was introduced to recognise police officers who perform acts of exceptional bravery in hazardous circumstances. First awarded in 1990 to Constables Kyle Bates, Edward Bennet, Neil Paulsen and Senior Constable Brendan Carew for a sea rescue.<ref name=":0" />
The Commissioner's Lantern Award was initiated to recognise and promote community-based policing. The inaugural 1991 winner was the Youth Assistance Panel project based in Townsville, joint initiative targeting petty juvenile offenders to provide a last chance before invoking the court system.<ref name=":0" />
The first custom built police headquarters was constructed on the block bounded by Makerston, Roma and Garrick Streets.<ref name=":0" />
New police badge, logo and the motto "With Honour We Serve" were adopted.<ref name=":0" />
In September the Computer Aided Despatch system was introduced which promises to improve the information available to, and increase the efficiency of, despatching police vehicles to incidents.<ref name=":0" />
=== 1991 === The Queensland Anti-Discrimination Act reinforces merit-based criteria in employment and the number of female recruits stabilises around thirty-three per cent.<ref name=":0" />
The Bureau of Criminal Intelligence develops and puts into operation the Queensland Intelligence Database with the ability to link nine different data categories.<ref name=":0" />
The Police Overseas Service Medal was established on 25 April to acknowledge the overseas peace-keeping role of police officers. The medal was awarded with a clasp which details the area of service.<ref name=":0" />
=== 1992 === The first female Chief Superintendent and Superintendent were appointed.<ref name=":0" />
The Queensland Equal Opportunity in Public Employment Act gives legislative support to initiatives to improve the position of women. These include flexible work options, anti-harassment strategies and mentor support.<ref name=":0" />
The Scientific Section relocates to the Roma Street Police Headquarters with more than 30 staff, many of whom specialise in a very select field of forensic identification.<ref name=":0" />
Electronic Recording Section becomes part of Forensic Services Branch<ref name=":0" />
The first Police Beat Shopfront was trialled at Rockhampton"s K-Mart Plaza and becomes a permanent establishment in August. This initiative was designed to provide an effective policing presence in shopping centres and to improve communication with the community.<ref name=":0" />
The Special Emergency Response Team was established to respond to emergency situations and to provide operational police with specialist support.<ref name=":0" />
An Executive Development Program commences to provide skills in strategic planning, policy development, resource management, and command and control to officers moving to commissioned rank.<ref name=":0" />
James Patrick O"Sullivan becomes the seventeenth Police Commissioner on 1 November 1992.<ref name=":0" />
=== 1993 === The offender identification computer system called Com-Fit was developed.<ref name=":0" />
The Task Force becomes the State Crime Operations Command with a primary function to generate intelligence about organised and major crime; and to support regional police during major criminal investigations.<ref name=":0" />
=== 1994 === The Public Safety Response Team was established as a fulltime unit with a staff of forty-five.<ref name=":0" />
On 24 October twelve passengers on a Wide Bay Tours bus, die when it crashes on the Gateway Motorway. Police, ambulance, fire and emergency service workers, work together to assist the injured after the accident.<ref name=":0" />
The Police Recruit Operational and Vocational Education (PROVE) program was introduced to allow recruit curricula to be run on a wholly in-Service basis.<ref name=":0" />
Between 1994 and 1996 the Academy was renamed as the Queensland Police and Emergency Services Academy in acknowledgement of the continuing training initiative between the Queensland Police and Queensland Emergency Services.<ref name=":0" />
In May, a new $3.3 million police complex, consisting of police station and watchhouse, was officially opened on Mornington Island. It was one of only four cyclone resistant buildings on the island and could be used as a cyclone shelter if required.<ref name=":0" />
=== 1995 === In response to the recommendations of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, the concept of Police Liaison Officers was initiated on Thursday Island and later trialled in Townsville.<ref name=":0" />
=== 1996 === The North Queensland Campus of the Police Academy was established in Townsville to encourage recruitment in central and northern Queensland.<ref name=":0" />
On 21 May Constable Shayne Gill was struck and killed by a motor vehicle while on radar duty on the [[Bruce Highway]] near [[Glasshouse Mountains]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.police.qld.gov.au/aboutUs/commemoration/inRemembrance/1986-1996.htm|title=In Remembrance: 1986-1996|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=[[Queensland Police]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170608214939/https://www.police.qld.gov.au/aboutUs/commemoration/inRemembrance/1986-1996.htm|archive-date=8 June 2017|dead-url=no|accessdate=9 June 2017}}</ref>
The North Queensland Police Service Academy in Townsville opens its doors for recruit training on 14 October.<ref name=":0" />
=== 1997 === The Violent Crime Analysis Unit was established to analyse [[victimology]], modus operandi, offender information, forensic data and behavioural patterns.<ref name=":0" />
The Volunteers in Policing (VIP) trial program was initiated in September. VIP duties at police stations include victim support, witness support, customer service, school support and community liaison.<ref name=":0" />
=== 1998 === Bicycles patrols were re-introduced to Brisbane after a successful trial.<ref name=":0" />
The Interactive Crime Scene Recording System was developed by the Photographic Section.<ref name=":0" />
The [[LIDAR traffic enforcement|laser speed gun]] was introduced; it uses [[Lidar|LIDAR]] (Light Detection and Ranging).<ref name=":0" />
A range of new equipment was introduced which includes extendable batons, hinged handcuffs and [[Glock]] firearms.<ref name=":0" />
=== 1999 === Women make up 17.36 per cent of sworn personnel. The number of female sworn officers increases steadily by approximately one per cent per year.<ref name=":0" />
The Queensland Police Service Medal was introduced on 1 January, to recognise the diligent and ethical service by members of the Queensland Police Service.<ref name=":0" />
The Queensland Government transfers the community police function from Community Councils at [[Woorabinda, Queensland|Woorabinda]], [[Yarrabah, Queensland|Yarrabah]] and on [[Badu Island]], to the Queensland Police as a 12 month pilot. These officers were known as Queensland Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Police (QATSIP).<ref name=":0" />
== 2000s ==
=== 2000 === Kathleen Rynders was the first policewoman to achieve the rank of Assistant Commissioner and in 2008 becomes the first woman to rise to the rank of Deputy Commissioner.<ref name=":0" />
All manual fingerprints filing systems were replaced by the National Automated Fingerprint Identification System allowing all states to share fingerprint information.<ref name=":0" />
The DNA Implementation Unit was established to facilitate the introduction of new legislation allowing the QPS to use [[DNA]] as a forensic investigative tool.<ref name=":0" />
The Crime Prevention Personal Safety Team develops a larger than life wooden figure named "Duncan" to assist in teaching children to pay attention to their gut feelings when they feel in danger.<ref name=":0" />
On 21 July 2000 Senior Constable Norman Watt, 33, was shot during an armed stand-off near [[Rockhampton]] in [[Central Queensland]].<ref name=":1"/>
Robert Atkinson becomes the eighteenth Police Commissioner on 1 November 2000.<ref name=":0" />
=== 2002 === In March 2002 co-ordination and security for Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting involves the largest security operation ever staged by the Queensland Police.<ref name=":0" />
A dedicated [[cold case]] team was established within the Homicide Investigation Group.<ref name=":0" />
In March co-ordination and security for [[Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting 2002|Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting]] was managed by the Queensland Police Service. More than 4,000 police and staff members take part in the security operation.<ref name=":0" />
=== 2003 === Constable Mokhtiar Singh creates history as the first [[Sikh]] to be sworn in as a Queensland police officer. His uniform includes an adaptation of the traditional [[Sikh turban|Indian turban]] in recognition of his cultural heritage and religious beliefs.<ref name=":0" />
Thirteen Queensland Disaster Victim Identification Squad officers were deployed to [[Bali]], as part of an Australian contingent, to assist the [[Indonesian Government]] following the terrorist attack.<ref name=":0" />
The Oxley Police Academy delivers a Justice Entry Program targeted at Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.<ref name=":0" />
On 22 August 2003 Senior Sergeant Perry Irwin, 42, was shot while investigating reports of gunfire in bushland at [[Caboolture]], north of Brisbane.<ref name=":1"/>
=== 2004 === Queensland police begins the sharing and searching of [[DNA sample|DNA samples]] from people and crime scenes at a national level on the newly operating National Criminal Investigative DNA Database (NCIDD).<ref name=":0" />
=== 2005 === In February the Service opens a Police Dog Development Complex. It"s hoped that this dog breeding facility will overcome a general lack of trainable dogs.<ref name=":0" />
Bright red, two door Monaro Highway patrol cars were introduced.<ref name=":0" />
As at 30 June there were 9310 police officers and 3153 support staff.<ref name=":0" />
The "Forensic Register" was fully deployed for remote data entry to provide a "paperless" case file solution at a scene of crime. All forensic film based cameras were replaced with digital SLR cameras to record crime scenes.<ref name=":0" />
Three new Queensland police awards were established: the Commissioners Commendation for Bravery, Commissioners Certificate for Notable Action and Commissioners Award for Meritorious or Special Service.<ref name=":0" />
The Commissioners Commendation for Bravery was first awarded to Senior Sergeant Mathew Rosevear, Sergeants Robert Duncan and Richard Downie; Constables Glen Lamont, Kim Adamson and John Lima.<ref name=":0" />
The eligibility criteria for the Humanitarian Overseas Service Medal originally established in 1999, were amended to enable recognition of humanitarian service provided in response to national disasters overseas. First awarded to Senior Sergeants Kenneth Rach and Scott McLaren for their disaster victim identification work after the Thailand tsunami.<ref name=":0" />
Queensland police, [[Cardwell, Queensland|Cardwell]] Lions Club and Cardwell Coast Guard go into partnership to provide free [[EPIRB|EPIRBs]] to departing bush walkers on the Thorsborne Trail on [[Hinchinbrook Island]] and Herbert River Gorge walk. The project aims to help rescuers find lost or injured hikers more quickly.<ref name=":0" />
On 18 July 2007, Constable Brett Irwin, 33, was shot while executing an arrest warrant for breach of bail at [[Keperra]], in northwest Brisbane.<ref name=":1"/>
=== 2006 === QPRIME a major new policing information system was launched. The system is used to record and manage all reportable police incidents. It allows easier access to information, less time is spent searching for information in different systems and reduces manual and paper-based processes.<ref name=":0" />
The Live-scan fingerprint scanning system was successfully rolled out across the state. These units were connected to the Crimtrac National Automated Fingerprint Identification System in Canberra.<ref name=":0" />
=== 2007 === The Photographic Section goes digital and acquires a digital mini-lab which means that photos taken at any Queensland crime scene were processed and printed almost immediately.<ref name=":0" />
=== 2008 === Operation Achilles concludes after more than 2 years of investigation resulting in the simultaneous execution of warrants across the world and the arrests of child sex offenders in Australia, the United States, Germany and the United Kingdom.<ref name=":0" />
The publication of district-based Neighbourhood Watch Crime Bulletins was launched in Cairns in October. Crime Bulletins provide information to the community to assist in clearing offences, and to provide details about crime prevention initiatives.<ref name=":0" />
=== 2009 === The eligibility criterion of the Queensland Police Service Medal was changed and was made available to living former members who served prior to the introduction of the medal in 1999.<ref name=":0" />
Newly designed patches and epaulettes were introduced. Epaulettes for the ranks of Senior Sergeant and below, now incorporate the words "Queensland Police".<ref name=":0" />
== 2010s ==
=== 2010 === Policelink was established to provide an alternative point of contact for reporting non-urgent crimes or incidents and for general police enquiries. A new national non-urgent police number was introduced.<ref name=":0" />
The National Police Service Medal was established on 9 November and recognises the special status that sworn police officers have because of their role protecting the community and represents a police officer"s past and future commitment to give ethical and diligent service. A minimum of 15 years' service is required to qualify for the medal.<ref name=":0" />
Communications Room Operator Andrew Heinrich, took a call at the Ipswich Police Communications Centre around 9pm on 25 September and remains calm and in control as he gives the mother CPR instructions to resuscitate her unconscious baby girl.<ref name=":0" />
The Fortitude Valley police station redevelopment project comprises two stages, the construction of a two-level "operational" building and the refurbished of the existing 1936 building.<ref name=":0" />
=== 2011 === Eight years after thirteen year old [[Daniel Morcombe]] was abducted from a [[Sunshine Coast, Queensland|Sunshine Coast]] road, an extensive police investigation locates and charges his killer with murder.<ref name=":0" />
The use of Automatic Number Plate Recognition technology was launched state-wide. The initial launch consisted of one unit being located at the State Traffic Support Branch for use in state wide traffic operations involving both specialist and local police.<ref name=":0" />
The floods of 2011 initiate the first use of Facebook and Twitter by the QPS Media and Public Affairs Branch to forge a direct link with the community by using social media to relentlessly issue accurate information and to fight rumours.<ref name=":0" />
Unprecedented floods affects much of Queensland and police were involved in all manner of support, including victim identification, missing persons coordination, anti-looting patrol and countless rescues in all manner of vehicles and vessels.<ref name=":0" />
On 29 May 2011 Detective Senior Constable Damien Leeding (CIB) was shot when he confronted an armed offender at the [[Pacific Pines, Queensland|Pacific Pines]] Tavern on the [[Gold Coast, Queensland|Gold Coast]]. Leeding died in hospital on 1 June three days after being shot.<ref name=":1"/>
=== 2012 === [[File:Queensland Police Commissioner, Ian Stewart, 2017.jpg|thumb|Queensland Police Commissioner, Ian Stewart, 2017]] The introduction and implementation of the Automatic Number Plate Recognition project delivers significant improvement and efficiencies in frontline traffic operations.<ref name=":0" />
The new "Police Recruit Pathway" selects applicants based on physical health and fitness, personal integrity, cognitive ability and literacy, psychological suitability, life and work experience and practical policing skills.<ref name=":0" />
Ian Duncan Hunter Stewart becomes the nineteenth Police Commissioner on 1 November 2012.<ref name=":0" />
=== 2013 === A new recruit program commences in January that increasingly expects recruits to perform realistic policing roles.<ref name=":0" />
On 3 March an armed gunman brings business in the Queen Street Mall to a halt. The situation was brought under control by the swift action of operational police and the Special Emergency Response Team.<ref name=":0" />
The Fatal 5 campaign on HSV Holdens, was launched which adds ‚Äúinattention‚Äù to "speed", "seat belts", "drink driving" and "driving tired" as the main causes of traffic crashes. The campaign was designed to catch the attention of road users and prompt them to be more careful on the roads.<ref name=":0" />
Under the Queensland Police Renewal Program the newly named State Crime Command includes the Child Safety and Sexual Crime Group, Drug and Serious Crime Group, Fraud and Cyber Crime Group and the Homicide Group.<ref name=":0" />
The strength of the Queensland Police Service at 30 June was 11,055 police officers, 371 police recruits and 3705 staff members.<ref name=":0" />
On 1 July, a new structure was approved and which means the reduction of Regions from eight to five and Districts from thirty to fifteen.<ref name=":0" />
Women make up more than twenty-five per cent of sworn personnel and serve in many varied roles across the state.<ref name=":0" />
The most northerly police station was on Thursday Island, the most southerly police station was at Hungerford, the most westerly station was at Camooweal and the most easterly police station was at Coolangatta.<ref name=":0" />
On 1 July the Forensic Services Group forms as a result of the QPS review. It consisted of more than 550 staff and encompasses all district scenes of crime units, the Fingerprint Bureau, the Forensic Intelligence Unit, and the DNA management, Photographic and Electronic Recording and Scientific sections. The FSG processes in excess 150,000 requests for service and positively identifies or links several thousand suspects to their crime each year.<ref name=":0" />
The mobile data pilot for smartphones and tablets was rolled in October as part of the move to provide the technology required by police to keep the community safe.<ref name=":0" />
At the Queensland Police Excellence Awards, Southern Region wins the Gold Lantern Award for Excellence in Problem-Oriented and Partnership for their "Stay on Track Outback" initiative which aims to enhance road safety on the rural and remote highways of outback Queensland.<ref name=":0" />
New uniform material was approved which is lighter in weight and more breathable. The cloth is treated with a flash dry and incorporates a percentage of stretch for comfort and ease.<ref name=":0" />
There were more than 450 police establishments spread across the state.<ref name=":0" />
=== 2014 === Queensland Police celebrated their 150th anniversary.<ref name=":0" />
=== 2017 === On 29 May 2017, Senior Constable Brett Forte was shot and killed at [[Adare, Queensland|Adare]], north of [[Gatton, Queensland|Gatton]], after attempting to apprehend a suspected offender. The gunman, Rick Maddison, was shot and killed the next day by police while trying to escape after a siege in a farmhouse at [[Ringwood, Queensland|Ringwood]], north-west of Gatton.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.couriermail.com.au/news/queensland/crime-and-justice/police-officer-brett-forte-shot-dead-in-lockyer-valley-west-of-brisbane/news-story/70e3a7f04d28845de973b519def0d2dd|title=Cop killer shot dead by police|author=Kate Kyriacou|author2=Thomas Chamberlin|date=30 May 2017|work=[[The Courier Mail]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170602034334/http://www.couriermail.com.au/news/queensland/crime-and-justice/police-officer-brett-forte-shot-dead-in-lockyer-valley-west-of-brisbane/news-story/70e3a7f04d28845de973b519def0d2dd|archivedate=2 June 2017|deadurl=no|accessdate=9 June 2017|author3=Chris Clarke|author4=David Sigston|df=dmy-all}}</ref> On 8 June 2018, the police helicopter POLAIR 2 was named Brett A. Forte in his honour.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.qt.com.au/news/police-helicopter-polair-2-named-brett-forte/3436922/|title=Polair 2 honour for slain Brett Forte|last=|first=|date=8 June 2018|work=[[The Queensland Times]]|access-date=30 November 2018}}</ref> POLAIR 2 had provided air support during the siege.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.couriermail.com.au/questnews/moreton/polair-2-has-been-named-after-senior-constable-brett-forte-who-was-shot-and-killed-on-duty/news-story/fe5a28255dc9d3cc4788c30fa0a74178|title=Polair 2 has been named after Senior Constable Brett Forte who was shot and killed on duty|last=Smith|first=Erin|date=8 June 2018|work=[[The Courier-Mail]]|access-date=30 November 2018}}</ref>
==References== [[File:Police officers of Queensland Police Service, on the beat, in Brisbane Australia.jpg|thumb|On the beat, 2018]]{{reflist}}

{{more citations needed|date=January 2013}} {{use dmy dates|date=October 2016}} {{use Indian English|date=October 2016}} {{Infobox legislation | imagesize = 100 | enacted_by = [[Parliament of India]] | status = repealed }} '''The Illegal Migrants (Determination by Tribunal ) (IMDT) Act''' was an [[Act of Parliament|Act]] of the [[Parliament of India]] enacted in 1983 by the [[Indira Gandhi]] government. It was struck down by the [[Supreme Court of India]] in 2005 in ''Sarbananda Sonowal v. Union of India''.
Known as the IMDT Act (1983) it described the procedures to detect illegal immigrants (from [[Bangladesh]]) and expel them from [[Assam]]. The Act was pushed through mainly on the grounds that it provided special protections against undue harassment to the ‚Äúminorities‚Äù affected by the [[Assam Agitation]]. It was applicable to the state of Assam only whereas in other states, detection of foreigners is done under [[The Foreigners Act, 1946]].
The act made it difficult to deport illegal immigrants from Assam. It has been alleged to be one of the main reasons for the rapid rise of the Muslim population and demographic change in Assam.
==Salient features== The Foreigners Act, 1946 defines a foreigner as a person who is not a citizen of India. Section 9 of the Act states that, where the nationality of a person is not evident as per preceding section 8, the onus of proving whether a person is a foreigner or not, shall lie upon such person.
However, under the Illegal Migrants (Determination by Tribunal ) (IMDT) Act, the burden of proving the citizenship or otherwise rested on the accuser and the police, not the accused. This was a major departure from the provisions of the Foreigners Act, 1946.
The accuser must reside within a 3 km radius of the accused, fill out a complaint form (a maximum of ten per accuser is allowed) and pay a fee of ten Rupees.
If a suspected illegal migrant is thus successfully accused, he is required by the Act to simply produce a ration card to prove his Indian citizenship.
And if a case made it past these requirements, a system of tribunals made up of retired judges would finally decide on deportation based on the facts.
The act also provided that 'if the application is found frivolous or vexatious' the Central Government may not accept it.
It excluded the migrants who entered India before March 25, 1971 from the illegal-migration accusation. And for post-1971 migrants too, the procedure for deporting were tough.
==Supreme Court's views== The Act was challenged by [[Sarbananda Sonowal]] in courts. In 2005 a three-judge Bench of the [[Supreme Court of India]] held that the Illegal Migrants (Determination by Tribunals) Act, 1983 and rules "has created the biggest hurdle and is the main impediment or barrier in the identification and deportation of illegal migrants" and struck down the Act.<ref>http://indiankanoon.org/doc/1436100/</ref>
The court also observed "(the conviction rate under the IMDT act) comes to less than half per cent of the cases initiated...(the IMDT Act) is coming to the advantage of such illegal migrants as any proceedings initiated against them almost entirely ends in their favour, enables them to have a document having official sanctity to the effect that they are not illegal migrants."
On 9 August 2012, the Supreme Court hearing a [[Public interest litigation in India|public interest litigation]] petition seeking a direction for deportation of illegal migrants, was told that the Government of India, as a matter of policy, "does not support any kind of illegal migration either into its territory or illegal immigration of its citizens. "It was also stated that the Government is committed to deporting illegal Bangladeshi migrants, but only lawfully. It asserted that the demand for deleting the names of alleged 41 lakh doubtful voters from the list of 2006 on the basis of religious and linguistic profiling would prima facie be illegal, arbitrary and violative of the secular and democratic credentials of India. The court posted the matter for final hearing on 6 November 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/article3747019.ece |title= Committed to deporting illegal migrants, but only lawfully: Centre|date=10-08-2012}}</ref>
==See also== [[The Foreigners Act,1946]]

'''The Japan‚ÄìKorea Treaty of 1882''', also known as the '''Treaty of Chemulpo''' or the ''Chemulpo Convention,'' was negotiated between [[Empire of Japan|Japan]] and [[Joseon|Korea]] following the [[Imo Incident]] in July 1882.<ref name="takenobu131">Takenobu, Yoshitaro. (1887). {{Google books|CJFKAAAAMAAJ|''The Japan Yearbook,'' p. 131.|page=131}}; excerpt, "''Korea agreed in the ''so-called Chemulpo Convention'' to pay [Japan] an indemnity and to build at her own cost barracks for the [Japanese] Legation guards''."</ref>
==Background== On July 23, 1882, factional strife between Koreans in Korea's capital expanded beyond the initial causes of the disturbance.<ref name="takenobu131"/>
[[File:ImoIncident ToyoharaChikanobu (2).jpg|thumb|right|"The Korean Uprising of 1882" — woodblock print by Toyohara Chikanobu, 1882]] As the violence unfolded, the Japanese legation was destroyed by rioters. The Japanese diplomats were forced to flee the country. When order was restored, the Japanese government demanded damages and other concessions form the Korean government.<ref name="takenobu131"/>
The negotiations were concluded in August 1882.
Article V of the "convention" permitted the Japanese to protect the Japanese legation and the Japanese community in Korea.<ref>Duus, Peter. (1995). {{Google books|DZaizVa8oAAC|''The Abacus and the Sword: The Japanese Penetration of Korea, 1895‚Äì1910''|page=69}}</ref>
In 1884, the Japanese forgave the ¬•400,000 indemnity which had been mandated by the treaty.<ref>Duus, {{Google books|DZaizVa8oAAC| p. 57.|page=57}}; Takenobu, p. 131; excerpt, "''Japan remitted the major portion of the indemnity on the understanding that it should be used for the purpose of internal reforms''."</ref>

{{flagicon|United Nations}} [[United Nations]] | ratifiers = | depositor = | depositories = *[[Indian government|Government of India]] * [[Government of Pakistan]] | | language = | languages = English | | wikisource = | wikisource1 = }} The '''Karachi Agreement''' of 1949 was signed by the military representatives of India and Pakistan, supervised by the [[United Nations Commission for India and Pakistan]], establishing a cease-fire line in [[Kashmir]] following the [[Indo-Pakistani War of 1947]].{{sfn|Wirsing, War or Peace on the Line of Control?|1998|p=9}} It established a cease-fire line which has been monitored by United Nations observers from the United Nations since then.{{sfn|Hilaire, United Nations Law and the Security Council|2005|pp=29-30}} ==Background== {{Main|United Nations Security Council Resolution 47}} The Security Council Resolution 47 of April 1948 established a UN Commission ([[United Nations Commission for India and Pakistan]] ‚Äî UNCIP) to mediate between India and Pakistan in order to bring about a cessation of [[Indo-Pakistani War of 1947|fighting]] in Kashmir and to make arrangements for a popular plebiscite. After negotiations with the two sides, the Commission passed a three-part resolution in August 1948 and subsequently added a 'supplement'. The three parts dealt with ceasefire, terms for truce, and procedures for negotiation regarding the plebiscite. Both the countries accepted the resolution and a ceasefire was achieved on 31 December 1948. ==Agreement== [[File:Kashmir Jammu Map.png|thumb|right|The princely state of Jammu and Kashmir with the current [[Line of Control]] defined in 1972 (similar to that of 1949)]] The Karachi Agreement, formally called the ''Agreement Between Military Representatives of India and Pakistan Regarding the Establishment of a Cease-Fire Line in the State of Jammu and Kashmir,'' was signed on 27 July 1949, supervised by the Truce Subcommittee of the UNCIP.{{sfn|Wirsing, War or Peace on the Line of Control?|1998|p=9}} The signatories were: # Lt. Gen. [[S. M. Shrinagesh]], on behalf of India # Maj. Gen. [[W. J. Cawthorn]], on behalf of Pakistan # Hernando Samper and M. Delvoie, on behalf of the UNCIP. The other members of the Indian delegation were Maj. Gen. [[K. S. Thimayya]], Brig. [[Sam Maneckshaw]], Maj. [[Srinivas Kumar Sinha|S. K. Sinha]] (who acted as the ''aide-de-camp'' for Gen. Srinagesh), and the secretaries of the Defence Ministry and the Ministry of Kashmir Affairs. The Pakistani delegation included Maj. Gen. Nazir Ahmed and Brig. Sher Khan and civil servants M. Ayub and A. A. Khan. The military representatives of the two sides negotiated for a week starting 18 July to demarcate the positions under their control.{{sfn|Bhattacharya, What Price Freedom|2013|pp=151‚Äì152}}{{citation |last=Ganguly |first=Sumit |title=Deadly Impasse |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=z_-lCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA134 |date=31 March 2016 |publisher=Cambridge University Press |isbn=978-0-521-76361-5 |pages=134‚Äì}} S. K. Sinha stated that the Prime Minister [[Jawaharlal Nehru]] briefed the Indian delegation before the Karachi meeting, wherein he informed them that the [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 47|UN Resolution]] conceded the legality of Kashmir's accession to India and, so, any "no man's land" would belong to India. The Pakistani delegation would need to produce proof to the UN Commission of factual positions of their control for all the territory they claim. Sinha stated that, based on this principle, the agreement demarcated several hundred square miles of territory on the Indian side even though there were no Indian troops in that territory.Claude Arpi, [http://www.dnaindia.com/analysis/column-the-myths-of-wild-roses-and-pakistani-presence-in-siachen-1694621 The myths of wild roses and Pakistani presence in Siachen], Daily News and Analysis, 28 May 2012. [[File:Page 2 - CFL as shown on UN Map to Karachi Agreement 1949.JPG|thumb|right|The ceasefire line of 1949]] The 830 kilometre long ceasefire line established in the agreement started from a southernmost point just west of the [[Chenab river]] in [[Jammu Division|Jammu]]. It ran in a rough arc northwards and then northeastwards to the map coordinate [[NJ9842]], about 19 km north of the [[Shyok river]].{{sfn|Wirsing, War or Peace on the Line of Control?|1998|pp=9-10}} From the map point NJ9842 it was said to run due north to the international boundary with China, at a distance of about 60‚Äì65 km. Since there were no troops in that area of inaccessible glacial terrain, no effort was made to extend the ceasefire line between NJ9842 and the China border. This area, of the [[Siachen Glacier]], eventually became a bone of contention between India and Pakistan.{{sfn|Wirsing, War or Peace on the Line of Control?|1998|p=10}} Another anomaly arose at the southern end of the ceasefire line in [[Jammu Division|Jammu]]. From the terminus of the ceasefire line to the international boundary between Indian and Pakistani [[Punjab]], there was a gap of over 200 km, which was covered by a recognised "provincial boundary" between Pakistani Punjab and the [[Jammu and Kashmir (princely state)|princely state of Jammu and Kashmir]]. India generally referred to this boundary as the "international border", whereas Pakistan referred to it as the "border" or the "working border".{{sfn|Wirsing, War or Peace on the Line of Control?|1998|p=10}} ==Map of the Agreement== [[U.N.]] document number S/1430/Add.2{{cite web|title=UN Map showing CFL - UN document number S/1430/Add.2|url=http://repository.un.org/bitstream/handle/11176/87063/S_1430_Add.2-EN.pdf?sequence=2&isAllowed=y|website=Dag Digital Library|accessdate=30 May 2015}} (which is the second [[addendum]] to the 1949 Karachi Agreement) shows the Cease Fire Line (CFL) marked on the Map of the State of [[Jammu and Kashmir]]. Title of this addendum reads:
Map of the State of Jammu and Kashmir showing the Cease Fire Line as Agreed Upon in the Karachi Agreement, Ratified by the Governments of India and Pakistan on 29 and 30 July Respectively. (See Annex 26 to the third Interim Report of the United Nation Commission for India and Pakistan){{citation|title=U.N. Commission for India and Pakistan: annexes to the interim report|publisher=Dag Digital Library - the United Nations|page=83|url=http://repository.un.org/bitstream/handle/11176/87062/S_1430_Add.1-EN.pdf?sequence=2&isAllowed=y|accessdate=3 June 2015|ref=Document symbol: S/1430/Add.1}}{{citation|title=Treaty Series|publisher=United Nations Treaty Collection|page=274|edition=Volume 81|url=https://treaties.un.org/doc/Publication/UNTS/Volume%2081/v81.pdf|accessdate=4 June 2015}}
=== U.N. Map illustrating Cease Fire Line as per Karachi Agreement === {|style="margin: 0 auto;" | [[File:Page 1 - CFL as shown on UN Map to Karachi Agreement 1949.JPG|thumb|Page-1 of U.N. Map Number S/1430/Add.2 to Karachi Agreement 1949]] | [[File:Page_2_-_CFL_as_shown_on_UN_Map_to_Karachi_Agreement_1949.JPG|thumb|Page-2 of U.N. Map Number S/1430/Add.2 showing CFL]] | [[File:Page 3 - CFL as shown on UN Map to Karachi Agreement 1949.JPG|thumb|Page-3 U.N. Map Number S/1430/Add.2 showing CFL terminating at NJ9842]] |} The Karachi Agreement between India and Pakistan established a cease-fire line to be supervised by the military observers. These observers, under the command of the [[Military Advisor]], formed the nucleus of the [[United Nations Military Observer Group in India and Pakistan]] (UNMOGIP). On 30 March 1951, following the termination of the United Nations Commission for India and Pakistan (UNCIP), the Security Council, by Resolution 91 (1951) decided that UNMOGIP should continue to supervise the cease-fire line in Kashmir. UNMOGIP's functions were to observe and report, investigate complaints of cease-fire violations and submit its findings to each party and to the Secretary General.[http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/time-un-observers-left-kashmir-india/article4330381.ece Time U.N. observers left Kashmir: India] ==See also== * [[NJ9842]] * [[Simla Agreement]] * [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 47]] * [[Karachi Agreement (Azad Kashmir)]] == References == {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20140214175655/http://www.kashmir-information.com/LegalDocs/KashmirCeasefire.html Complete text of the agreement] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20140223015415/http://www.kashmir-information.com/historicaldocuments/kashmirceasefire.html Text of Agreement] *[http://peacemaker.un.org/node/1091 Full text of the Karachi Agreement], UN Peacemaker *[http://repository.un.org/bitstream/handle/11176/87063/S_1430_Add.2-EN.pdf?sequence=2&isAllowed=y UN Map showing CFL as per Karachi Agreement - UN document number S/1430/Add.2], Dag Digital Library - the United Nations *[http://repository.un.org/bitstream/handle/11176/87062/S_1430_Add.1-EN.pdf?sequence=2&isAllowed=y UN Commission for India and Pakistan: annexes to the interim report], Annex 26 *[http://peacemaker.un.org/document-search?keys=&field_padate_value%5Bvalue%5D%5Bdate%5D=&field_pacountry_tid=india All peace agreement for India], UN Peacemaker *[http://peacemaker.un.org/document-search?keys=&field_padate_value%5Bvalue%5D%5Bdate%5D=&field_pacountry_tid=pakistan All peace agreements for Pakistan], UN Peacemaker == Bibliography == * {{citation |last=Bhattacharya |first=Brig. Samir |title=NOTHING BUT!: Book Three: What Price Freedom |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HESVAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA42 |date=2013 |publisher=Partridge Publishing |isbn=978-1-4828-1625-9 |ref={{sfnref|Bhattacharya, What Price Freedom|2013}}}} * John Cherian, [http://www.frontline.in/navigation/?type=static&page=flonnet&rdurl=fl1615/16151210.htm Spotlight on Siachen], Frontline, 17 July 1999 * {{citation |last=Hilaire |first=Max |title=United Nations Law And the Security Council |publisher=Ashgate Publishing, Ltd |year=2005 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8m5E_TrIkXEC&pg=PA29 |ref={{sfnref|Hilaire, United Nations Law and the Security Council|2005}}}} * {{citation |last=Wirsing |first=Robert |title=War or Peace on the Line of Control? The India-Pakistan Dispute over Kashmir Turns Fifty |publisher=University of Durham, International Boundaries Research Unit |year=1998 |pages=9‚Äì11 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CqsA-YVuV2UC&pg=PA9 |isbn=1-897643-31-4 |ref={{sfnref|Wirsing, War or Peace on the Line of Control?|1998}}}} ==External links== * [http://peacemaker.un.org/sites/peacemaker.un.org/files/IN%20PK_490729_%20Karachi%20Agreement.pdf Karachi Agreement], United Nations Peacemaker website. {{India-Pakistan relations}} [[Category:Peace treaties of Pakistan]] [[Category:Peace treaties of India]] [[Category:Treaties involving territorial changes]] [[Category:Kashmir]] [[Category:India‚ÄìPakistan relations]] [[Category:1949 in India]] [[Category:1949 in Pakistan]] [[Category:Treaties concluded in 1949]] [[Category:Treaties entered into force in 1949]] [[Category:Treaties of the Dominion of India]] [[Category:India‚ÄìPakistan treaties]] [[Category:Government of Liaquat Ali Khan]]
